    | 1953|1953|2006-09-01 12:15:54|Nathaniel Bennett|AGoT General Strategy Notes|
    I've joined the AGoT board game Yahoo group and
    compiled these general strategy notes from several
    posts. Sorry the formatting sucks.

    *Spread out! Give your armies room to grow, especially
    early in the
    game. Be ready for when a muster card appears. Don't
    be caught
    huddled around your cities and strongholds. In each of
    the first and
    second rounds of the game, try to take a
    city/stronghold territory
    AND a territory with a barrel. Supply and mustering go
    hand in hand.
    Don't ignore the barrels in favor of
    cities/strongholds for
    mustering. You'll regret it later

    *Don't forget raids, and use them for more than
    removing an
    opponent's consolidate power tokens. Use them to
    remove support, and
    watch your foes squirm. This may seem elementary, but
    I think that
    raids are too often overlooked (at least in my group).
    We have these
    huge number crunching battles with these high attack
    and defend
    values, a great portion of which come from support.
    There is nothing
    better than wiping out support that someone is
    depending on for
    their survival.

    *Yes, the sword token is greatbut don't forget the
    raven token! It
    is a great tool for feints and trickery, especially
    when it might be
    time to turn an ally into an enemy. Use its ability
    that allows you
    to switch a played order for an unplayed order to
    create confusion
    and set up ambushes. And if you can get your hands on
    both the sword
    and the raven at the same time, even better! Both of
    these tokens
    should not be ignored. If you have one (or both), you
    should be
    thinking of how to use them EVERY TURN!

    *Ships are there for more than just support and raids!
    Always be
    aware of where your ships can potentially serve as
    "bridges" for
    your troops. Use them for long-range attacks,
    especially when you
    think your opponent is not aware of their peril!
    Watching the
    expression of someone you just ambushed via a "ship
    bridge" is
    priceless! Be cunning with those ships!

    *During the Clash of Kings, do not bid "blindly."
    Always have a
    reason for bidding what you bid, and always keep
    thinking about how
    each area of influence pertains to your strategy.
    Don't grab for
    those influence tokens just to have them! If you know
    that you need
    to wage some battles in the next turn or so, go for
    the sword. If
    you need to be crafty, go for the raven. If you want
    to mess with
    your opponents' positions on the influence tracks, get
    the throne!
    And don't be afraid to let those tokens go when the
    time is right,
    either. Don't bankrupt yourself, spending all your
    power tokens,
    just to hold on to an influence token!

    *Develop your group's fluency with (and comfort with)
    table talk! It
    spices up a game and gives it great flavor, especially
    if there are
    people in your group that have read the books in the
    series. Sneer
    and jeer, make and break alliances, call each other
    "blackguards"
    and "whoresons" and whatnot. But always remember that
    it is all in
    fun and don't take it too seriously. It really adds
    something to the
    experience.

    *Try to use multiple adjacent marches to confuse foes.
    You can, for
    example, march units from one or more different
    territories into an
    area that already has a march token to build up your
    strength before
    launching a major attack. If your opponent sees
    multiple marches
    across a front, they will not know from which
    territory an attack
    may come until it is too late. This becomes especially
    deadly when
    used in conjunction with the raven token. In general,
    always
    remember that it's the attack the enemy does not see
    coming that
    hurts them the most. Use feints whenever you can.

    *Always take the opportunity to dig through your
    opponent's
    character graveyard to see which House characters they
    have used.
    Use process of elimination to determine what cards
    they have left in
    their hand before attacking them.

    *Don't let emotions carry you away! Be calm, and
    remember to not let
    a lost battle bring you down. Your fortunes can change
    a lot in this
    game, and very quickly. Don't convince yourself that
    you are ever
    out of the game because of your mistakes, especially
    early on. Don't
    declare someone your mortal enemy just because they
    attack you.
    Remember to not let your emotions show too much, keep
    a game face
    on. Watch the reactions of your enemies closely. "Know
    your enemy,"
    as Sun Tzu says in The Art of War.

    *Always seek to take the chance to make pacts and
    temporary
    alliances. This can take pressure off of you so you
    can focus on
    just a few enemies at a time, instead of trying to
    fight all of your
    opponents at once. And always be on the lookout for
    opportunities to
    pit your foes against one another. REMEMBER: The enemy
    of your enemy
    is your friend

    -Move last.
    -Support orders are huge, and can help in solidifying
    your front while
    you move up fresh troops or just consolidate
    elsewhere.
    -Watch your supply. Keep in mind you needn't hold the
    territory with
    supply, so can leave it empty or occupied by other
    houses until you
    need it.
    -In keeping with supply above, don't spend alot of
    power controlling
    territory. For the most part, I tend to spend power to
    control only
    muster points that I will be leaving empty.
    -Don't overbid on influence, or bid just because the
    sword/throne/raven
    looks cool. Think carefully on what form of influence
    you most need
    for the upcoming turn(s) and bid on that. Estimate who
    your
    competitors for that track will be based on the board
    situation and
    watch their power closely, then bid apprpriately.
    -Naval marches (moving land forces via navies) are
    lethal, as they can
    move forces far more rapidly across the board than on
    land. Watch for
    this. Combined with the powerful support orders, this
    means you must
    control the sea to a certain degree. Without which,
    you likely cannot
    win the game.
    -Options. When placing orders, give yourself the most
    options. Having
    multiple routes of attack/retreat combined with
    multiple marches are
    key. When used with naval marches and the move last
    doctrine, you can
    decide when and where to hit the hardest.


    __________________________________________________
    Do You Yahoo!?
    Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around
    http://mail.yahoo.com
    | 1954|1953|2006-09-01 18:51:31|Mark Simpson|Re: AGoT General Strategy Notes|
    >>>>> "Nathaniel" == Nathaniel Bennett <nathaniel_bennett@yahoo.com> writes:

    Nathaniel> *Ships are there for more than just support and raids!
    Nathaniel> Always be aware of where your ships can potentially
    Nathaniel> serve as "bridges" for your troops. Use them for
    Nathaniel> long-range attacks, especially when you think your
    Nathaniel> opponent is not aware of their peril!

    Nathaniel> Watching the expression of someone you just ambushed
    Nathaniel> via a "ship bridge" is priceless!

    Yeah... tell me about it!

    BTW: i checked out a review entitled 'My Enduring Hatred' (the guy
    played 4 turns and hates the game, and will right a nice long rant to
    let you know about it). He does point out one interesting game
    problem:

    If you lose all your ships and none of your muster points have open
    seas adjacent to them (because opponent ships are in those locations)
    then you can never build ships. The new units need to be placed in
    friendly or empty locations and you can't attack from land to water.
    | 1955|1955|2006-09-06 09:10:20|Nathaniel Bennett|Lords, call your bannermen|
    My fellow Lords of Westeros,

    King Robert lies in his grave. and by the laws of man
    and The Seven my claim to the throne is sacrosanct. I
    have called my bannermen and have begun my coronation
    march to Kings Landing. As we agreed I will meet you
    in Burlington tomorrow evening so that you may bend
    the knee and swear allegiance.

    Until then may the Mother protect you if your heart is
    good and your intentions pure, and may the Warrior
    strike you down if deceit darkens your heart.

    __________________________________________________
    Do You Yahoo!?
    Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around
    http://mail.yahoo.com
    | 1956|1955|2006-09-06 21:42:20|Mark Simpson|Re: Lords, call your bannermen|
    See you tomorrow

    | 1957|1957|2006-09-08 16:17:45|Nathaniel Bennett|Game of Thrones expansion options|
    I've read the Clash of Kings expansion rules for A
    Game of Thrones and it would be very easy to add most
    of the expansion options. Here's a rundown of whats
    added:

    FORTIFICATIONS
    By spending a Consolidate Power order you can build
    fortifications which give defending units +1 combat
    power. Fortifications are destroyed if all defending
    units leave the territory.

    SIEGE ENGINES
    Siege Engines are a new unit. They cost 2 to muster
    (like knights) and have combat strength 4 when
    attacking cities, strongholds or foritifications, and
    combat strength 0 when attacking any other unit type
    or defending. Siege engines can't retreat and are
    destroyed if forced to retreat.

    PORTS
    Eight ports are added to the map. Ports are additional
    locations that are essentially part of the land
    territory they are on. They allow for additional ship
    unit mustering, and they allow ships to Consolidate
    Power.

    ONE TIME ORDERS
    Four new order types which can each only be used once
    per game. They reduce the randomness of the card draws
    for the most part. They are:

    Recruit (you muster in that location)
    Supply Caravan (increase your supply by the amount of
    the territory).
    Forced March (move as many units from adjacent
    territories as you'd like)
    House specific one time orders, which vary per house.

    Playing with the new rules probbaly makes the game
    longer so that we'd need two weeks to finish a game.
    What do y'all think?

    __________________________________________________
    Do You Yahoo!?
    Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around
    http://mail.yahoo.com

    the knee and swear allegiance.

    Until then may the Mother protect you if your heart is
    good and your intentions pure, and may the Warrior
    strike you down if deceit darkens your heart.

    | 1970|1970|2006-10-06 09:06:39|Nathaniel Bennett|Pandemonium: State of the Store|
    The financial situation of Pandemonium came up last
    night so I've pasted the State of the Store posted to
    Pandemonium's livejournal blog.

    The State of the Store and Plans for the Future

    In regards to the stores financial situation, let me
    hasten to inform everybody that this does not mean the
    end of the store. Sure, things are dire, but in
    Pandemoniums 18-year history, this sort of thing has
    happened before. Cash goes crunch, and then we have
    to live on hardtack for a year or two. I had hoped
    that we would be able to avoid this sort of austerity
    program, but things did not work out that way. It
    sucks, but the store is likely to survive. Now that we
    have made these painful cuts, our money situation
    should start improving slooowly over the next few
    months. If we ignore the Mecha Debt (and lets, shall
    we?), Pandemonium is otherwise in a pretty good
    position. We successfully made the move to Central
    Square, keeping the core of our customer base. Events
    at the store are beginning to gain momentum, and I
    hope to see business pick up as a result of that.
    Additionally, while we will be losing our full-time
    employees, I have been deeply impressed by the quality
    and dedication of our part-timers. Over the last
    three months, they have taken on increasingly larger
    amounts of the workload and I am confident that they
    will be able to handle their responsibilities without
    constant supervision. I hope that the people who come
    to work at the store in the next month will be of the
    same caliber.

    However, we cannot lose sight of the fact that the
    store still needs to significantly increase its
    revenues if it is going to get out of its current
    situation with any speed. Having looked at this
    problem for awhile now, I am actually not going to ask
    people to spend more at Pandemonium. While it would
    be good for us in the short term, it would mean poorer
    customers and lower sales in the longer term.

    So what should we do?

    What the store needs now is not more money per se, but
    rather more regular customers. While Pandemoniums
    customer base is extremely loyal, it is not very
    large. The store only has about one thousand regular
    customers (regular defined as someone who comes in
    at least once every sixty days). When I was drafting
    my business plan in school last year, I calculated
    that the store only got about 3-4% of the total
    science fiction literature market of the greater
    Boston area. There is a very large number of fans in
    the Boston area who simply are unaware of the stores
    very existence. I think this is especially true on
    the college campuses in Boston proper and in the
    suburbs beyond the reach of public transportation.
    Our task then is to increase Boston fan awareness of
    the store.

    Even as I write this, commercials for the store are
    playing on the SciFi Channel in the 86,000 RCN
    households of the Metro Boston area. This is our
    first foray into cable advertising, and while I have
    hopes for it, I think there is a better way to let
    people know about the store.


    Missionaries Wanted!

    One of the things I learned about in business school
    is how very, very effective word-of-mouth can be in
    insuring the success of a business. Starbucks, for
    example, does virtually no advertising. They built
    the stores and people came. Of course, they built
    stores people wanted to come to, stores that customers
    were willing to recommend to their friends.
    Pandemonium has relied on word-of-mouth nearly
    exclusively over the last 18 years. Now, with your
    cooperation, we would like to do so again in a more
    directed effort, in what I am calling Pandemoniums
    Missionary Fan program.

    Its a simple referral program. Anyone who comes into
    the store and becomes a store member as a result of a
    customer recommendation will receive a 20% discount
    off their first purchase. Furthermore, if that new
    customer buys at least $50 within the first year of
    membership, the customer who recommended the new
    member will receive $5 in store credit. It this way,
    everyone benefits. The new customer gets a great
    discount (plus discovers a new store), the referring
    customer gets a little reward, and the store gets a
    new customer.

    This is how it will work: in the next few days,
    customers will be able to pick up Missionary cards at
    the store. Recommending customers (Missionaries)
    write their names on one side of the card, and give
    them out to friends who have not yet become store
    members (Converts). The Convert simply fills out
    the other side of the card (name, zip code,
    email/phone#), and brings it in on their first visit.

    If this program generates even 100 new regular
    customers, it will give the store a major long-lasting
    boost. I hope customers reading this will take a
    moment to look around to see if you have perhaps one
    or two friends who have never gotten around to
    visiting the store. The program, like Pandemonium
    itself, depends on your participation to make it work.
    Thanks again to all the wonderful customers, past,
    present and future, who have helped Pandemonium stay
    alive for 18 years, and hopefully will keep it alive
    for another 18 years.

    See you in the store!

    __________________________________________________

    This is the Star Wars conversion for HeroQuest. Its a
    good source for Aspect and Stunt inspiration since
    Heroquest used Keywords which are very similar. The
    pdf includes data on some of the main planets and
    species, and some tech stuff.

    | 1989|1989|2006-11-09 11:59:24|Nathaniel Bennett|[Star Wars] Force Stunts|
    Here are some details on a couple of Force Stunts.

    JEDI STUNTS


    Attuned: Living Force [Force]
    Don't center on your anxiety, Obi-Wan. Keep your
    concentration on the here and now where it belongs. Be
    mindful of the living Force, my young Padawan.
    -Qui-Gon Jinn, The Phantom Menace

    Requires Force: Great

    Qualities
     When the character gets Spin on a Force sense test,
    the result will be inflected by their close
    association to the Living Force, usually granting the
    character some additional insight concerning the
    immediate moment.
     (Maneuver) May use Spin on an Ability test
    associated with Force Body, Mind, or Project to swap
    Initiative order with one opponent (or minion group)
    on the following Exchange, once per Exchange.
     (Reaction) May spend a Force Point once per Exchange
    for a +2 bonus on an Initiative or Reaction test.

    Notes
    The Character is attuned to the Living Force of the
    moment, and is quick to respond to danger.


    Attuned: Unified Force [Force]
    Concentrate...feel the Force flow. Yes. Good. Calm,
    yes. Through the Force, things you will see. Other
    places. The future...the past. Old friends long gone.
     Yoda, Empire Strikes Back

    Requires Force: Great

    Qualities
     When the character gets Spin on a Force sense test,
    the result will be inflected by their close
    association to the Unified Force perspective, usually
    granting the character some additional insight
    associated with this perspective.
     (Meditation) May use Spin on an extended Force
    Ability test (as meditation) to enter a trance where
    they can intuit a new fact about something, from a
    remote "big picture" perspective.
     (Visions) May spend a Force Point (player or GM with
    player consent) once per Chapter to receive a Force
    Vision.

    Notes
    The Character is attuned to the "big picture" of the
    Force, and will tend to perceive things from that
    perspective.


    Force Psychometry [Force]
    I feel cold, death.  Luke Skywalker, Empire Strikes
    Back

    Requires Force related Aspect

    Qualities
     May spend a Force Point, once per Scene, in
    conjunction with a Force Ability test to pick up a
    fact, from a Scene or object, by reading the psychic
    impressions of what has gone before Awareness
    Complements this test. The character must spend the
    entire scene in concentration; violent distractions
    may make this very difficult.
     May spend a Force Point for +1 to Awareness or
    Search tests, involving impressions of a place or
    object, for one Scene, once per Scene.

    Notes
    Must spend time touching an object (or occupying a
    place) for some time to acquire a read.


    Force Shockwave [Force]

    Requires Force: Good

    Qualities
     TBD

    Notes
    TBD


    The Force is My Ally [Force]
    For my ally is the Force. And a powerful ally it
    is.-Yoda, Empire Strikes Back

    Requires Force: Good or an Aspect such as Jedi Prodigy

    Qualities
     The characters Jedi Aspect (Jedi Padawan, Jedi
    Knight, Jedi Master, etc.) may be Compelled whenever
    the character significantly increases their own risk
    by relying on the Force instead of taking some other
    more seemingly advantageous solution (such as using
    the ships targeting computer, or throwing a handy
    thermal detonator when confronted by an overwhelming
    group of minions).
     The character may spend a Force Point to resist all
    fear or intimidation for one Scene, by trusting in the
    Force.

    Notes
    The character places their faith in the Force, and it
    answers them.


    The Blade is the Heart of the Jedi [Lightsaber]
    The crystal is the heart of the blade.
    The heart is the crystal of the Jedi.
    The Jedi is the crystal of the Force.
    The Force is the blade of the heart.
    All are intertwined: The crystal,The blade,The Jedi.
    You are one.
    - Traditional Jedi lightsaber ceremony

    Requires Lightsaber: Fair

    Qualities
     The character has a +2 bonus to all Resolve tests
    while engaged in combat with a lightsaber.
     May spend a Force Point to recover/retain their
    Lightsaber if it is lost or they are disarmed.

    Notes
    Has a tremendous ability to remain focused when in
    combat with their Lightsaber, and never (or rarely) is
    it lost.





    ____________________________________________________________________________________
    Cheap talk?
    Check out Yahoo! Messenger's low PC-to-Phone call rates.
    http://voice.yahoo.com
    | 1990|1990|2006-11-09 12:22:27|Nathaniel Bennett|[Star Wars] Default skills|
    There's been some confusion regarding default stunts
    and skill levels for Force users that I wanted to
    clear up.

    Force skill
    Unless the character take a Force related Aspect (eg
    Jedi Knight, Jedi Padawan) the character's default
    rating in the Force skill is terrible. If the
    character does have a Force related Aspect they may
    spend and ability slot of their choice on the Force
    skill.

    Typical starting Force skills:

    Superb: Jedi Master
    Great: Jedi Knight (experienced)
    Good: Jedi Knight (novice)
    Fair: Jedi Padawan (experienced)
    Average: Jedi Padawan (novice), Untrained Force
    Prodigy
    Mediocre: Highly Force-sensitive non-Jedi, Jedi
    Initiate
    Poor: Slightly Force-sensitive non-Jedi
    Terrible: Typical Galactic Citizen

    Lightsaber Skill
    The Lightsaber skill defaults to Poor. Characters with
    Aspects that would expose them to Lightsaber training
    may spend a skill slot on the Lightsaber skill.




    ____________________________________________________________________________________
    Want to start your own business?
    Learn how on Yahoo! Small Business.
    http://smallbusiness.yahoo.com/r-index
    | 1991|1990|2006-11-09 12:33:29|widderslainte|Re: [Star Wars] Default skills|
    Nathaniel Bennett wrote:
    > There's been some confusion regarding default stunts
    > and skill levels for Force users that I wanted to
    > clear up.

    So our Jedi status aspect determine the highest slot we can choose for
    our Force skill. What determines our Jedi status - group consensus?
    Not that character balance is a huge consideration, but it sounds like a
    pretty significant difference (especially when it comes to stunt
    availability) if one of us is play a Jedi Master and the rest are Padawans.

    > Force skill
    > Unless the character take a Force related Aspect (eg
    > Jedi Knight, Jedi Padawan) the character's default
    > rating in the Force skill is terrible. If the
    > character does have a Force related Aspect they may
    > spend and ability slot of their choice on the Force
    > skill.
    >
    > Typical starting Force skills:
    >
    > Superb: Jedi Master
    > Great: Jedi Knight (experienced)
    > Good: Jedi Knight (novice)
    > Fair: Jedi Padawan (experienced)
    > Average: Jedi Padawan (novice), Untrained Force
    > Prodigy
    > Mediocre: Highly Force-sensitive non-Jedi, Jedi
    > Initiate
    > Poor: Slightly Force-sensitive non-Jedi
    > Terrible: Typical Galactic Citizen

    So far the Force skills we've got...

    Shawn's chracter: Great
    Logan's Experienced Padawan: Good
    Mark's Experienced Padawan: Fair

    Your Great means you're either an experienced Knight
    or a Prodigy. Logan's Good and Mark's Fair fit their characters.

    | 2000|2000|2006-11-14 09:09:05|Nathaniel Bennett|Capt. Jack Sparrow|
    From the thread "[CharCreation] Stat Capt. Jack
    Sparrow" here's Capt. Jack for Spirit of the Century.

    Captain Jack Sparrow (at the beginning of the first
    film)

    Aspects:
    I Owe Davy Jones
    Captain of the Black Pearl
    "Not without my effects!"
    One Last Shot
    Seemingly Perpetual Drunkenness
    The Compass of Tia Dalma
    Sucker for a Pretty Face
    The Pirate's Code
    "That's got to be the worst pirate I've ever seen."
    "That's got to be the best pirate I've ever seen."

    Skills:
    Superb - Sleight of Hand
    Great - Contacting, Burglary
    Good - Weapons, Athletics, Leadership
    Fair - Endurance, Sailing*, Deceit, Gambling
    Average - Fists, Stealth, Survival, Alertness, Guns

    Stunts: Bump and Grab, Sucker Punch, I Know a Guy Who
    Knows a Guy, One
    Hand on the Wheel, Anything Goes

    Fate Points: 10

    * Sailing is the same as Drive, 'cept for boats.

    | 2001|2001|2006-11-14 10:59:06|Nathaniel Bennett|Stunts & Advancement|
    I've been thinking more about Advancement and power
    levels and I'd rather start play with three Stunts as
    opposed to Five. I think I mentioned this last week
    but I'm don't remember what y'all thought of it. Would
    any character be crippled with only three stunts to
    start?

    SotC recommends half as many Stunts as Aspects, so my
    proposed Advancement Scheme is...

    Skill
    Skill
    Skill
    Skill & Aspect
    Skill
    Skill
    Skill
    Skill, Aspect & Stunt
    Lather, Rinse Repeat.



    ____________________________________________________________________________________
    Do you Yahoo!?
    Everyone is raving about the all-new Yahoo! Mail beta.
    http://new.mail.yahoo.com

    | 2006|2006|2006-11-15 23:26:30|---|Advancement?|
    > I've been thinking more about Advancement and power
    > levels and I'd rather start play with three Stunts as
    > opposed to Five. I think I mentioned this last week
    > but I'm don't remember what y'all thought of it. Would
    > any character be crippled with only three stunts to
    > start?
    >
    > SotC recommends half as many Stunts as Aspects, so my
    > proposed Advancement Scheme is...
    >
    > Skill
    > Skill
    > Skill
    > Skill & Aspect
    > Skill
    > Skill
    > Skill
    > Skill, Aspect & Stunt
    > Lather, Rinse Repeat.


    So coming from a background of D&D I'm used to getting experience
    points every session. I didn't get the impression that we would be
    getting a skill point every session we played for this game. However,
    if we only get one skill point for each completed story arc then I
    believe advancement will be incredibly slow. At that rate we would
    only gain one or two new stunts over the course of one whole year of
    real life.

    I guess the question is where is the balance?

    What do you all think? Is my sense of the rate of advancement way off?

    ~Logan
    | 2007|2007|2006-11-16 10:11:55|widderslainte|Rules Questions|
    * Dark Side Points - I understand why and how we get them. How are they
    used? How do we get rid of them, and what are the long term effects?

    * Weapons - What are the modifiers for armour, lightsabers,
    vibroweapons, and blasters in combat?

    S.

    --
    -------------------------
    widderslainte@comcast.net
    | 2008|2006|2006-11-16 10:20:52|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Advancement?|
    > What do you all think? Is my sense of the rate of
    > advancement way off?

    I plan to give out a skill point during any session in
    which significant stuff happens. So everyone gets a SP
    for last night, but not for the first session. That
    work for everyone?

    | 2009|2009|2006-11-16 10:20:56|Nathaniel Bennett|Player contributions|
    This is an open invitation to earn Force Points for
    player contributions. Shawn earns one for next session
    for bringing soundtracks (should have given it to him
    for last night), and Logan will earn one if he brings
    the Force cheat sheet. Any session where you bring a
    contribution you get an extra FP.

    The most useful player contribution would be a journal
    or outline of each session. Doesn't have to be in
    character, can just be bullet points of what happened.

    Art, handouts, music, multi-media, anything that makes
    the game more cool gets rewarded.

      | 2013|2013|2006-11-16 11:40:46|---|The Force in Combat|
      I like the idea behind our system so far. Keeping track of Force Usage
      and requiring an Endurance test once things have settled.

      I had an idea that may or may not enhance this let me know what you guys think.

      For the Endurance test you get a modifier based on your training in
      the Force. Somewhat like flipping the normal ladder upside down. This
      scale is really rough so other numbers/divisions may be more
      appropriate.

      +4 Jedi Grand Master
      +3 Jedi Master
      +2 Jedi Knight (Experienced)
      +1 Jedi Knight (Young)
      0 Padawan (Experienced)
      -1 Padawan (Young)
      -2 Initiate
      -3 Untrained Force Prodigy
      -4 Force Sensitive
      -5 Minor Force Sensitive
      -6 Mundane

      I feel that the way we have it now is almost too dependant on Endurance.

      For example we know that Yoda is getting on in his years. Thus his
      Endurance (without Force augmentation) probably isn't Legendary. Yet,
      as a Grand Master he shouldn't be fatigued from simple force use
      during combat.

      I think this makes force use easier to handle for experienced users or
      very tough people. If you happen to be very tough and very experienced
      well then you get extra bang for your buck.

      An alternate way of handling it with the same idea is that instead of
      a modifier to the Endurance roll, more experienced users get X phantom
      Force Ticks/Pips that they can expend before marking usage as normal.
      Does that make sense?


      What do you all think? Would this make the game better or add needless crunch?


      Also what should we call it?

      Force Pips
      Force Ticks
      Energy Points
      Force Reserve
      | 2014|2007|2006-11-16 12:08:24|David Beebe|Re: Rules Questions|
      I think that Dark Side points should have more lasting effects. (but not be impossible to clear out of the system)
       
      It's been a while since I've read the original d6 rules or the d20 rules but if I recall, you really needed to do 'heroic' things to flush them.
       
      We could do something like the paradox wheel from White-wolf (Mage) in that DSP prevents you from getting more LSP and you can only spend DSP on selfish things. (but that implies some max number of total fate/force points you could aquire) (this idea is half-baked and came to me 2 minutes ago)
       
      On 11/16/06, --- <oronisk@gmail.com> wrote:
      > * Dark Side Points - I understand why and how we get them. How are they
      > used? How do we get rid of them, and what are the long term effects?
      >
      >  * Weapons - What are the modifiers for armour, lightsabers,
      >  vibroweapons, and blasters in combat?
      >
      >  S.


      I think that unless you take an aspect or a stunt for your
      weapon/armor/lightsaber/etc etc it doesn't have any mechanical effect.
      Beyond that of altering what skill you use in combat that is. For
      example with a Lightsaber in my hand I can use my Lightsaber skill to
      defend, but without it I'm using Athletics.

      At least that is the impression I got from the rules...

      DSP = Dark Side Point
      LSP = I'm sure you can figure it out...


      For DSP, one mechanic that we used on the fly last night was a Resolve
      roll to convert a DSP into a LSP. If we decide we want to keep that
      mechanic I feel that the base difficulty of that roll should be fairly
      high, but if take steps up the time scale you get a bonus on the roll.
      The time scale was on that handy little cheat sheet Nate had last
      night.

      So that if you spend a whole day calming your emotions and meditating
      even without great resolve you are still likely to rid yourself of a
      DSP. The downside to doing it that way is that DSPs have no
      permanence. It is almost like saying "Sure I can give in to Satan as
      long as I spend a sufficient amount of time repenting on Sunday in
      Church"...

      So now that I've typed that out, maybe it isn't such a great idea...

      Thoughts?

      | 2015|2007|2006-11-16 12:19:46|---|Re: Rules Questions|
      > * Dark Side Points - I understand why and how we get them. How are they
      > used? How do we get rid of them, and what are the long term effects?
      >

      > vibroweapons, and blasters in combat?
      >

      I think that unless you take an aspect or a stunt for your
      weapon/armor/lightsaber/etc etc it doesn't have any mechanical effect.
      Beyond that of altering what skill you use in combat that is. For
      example with a Lightsaber in my hand I can use my Lightsaber skill to
      defend, but without it I'm using Athletics.

      DSP = Dark Side Point

      roll to convert a DSP into a LSP. If we decide we want to keep that
      mechanic I feel that the base difficulty of that roll should be fairly
      high, but if take steps up the time scale you get a bonus on the roll.
      The time scale was on that handy little cheat sheet Nate had last
      night.

      So that if you spend a whole day calming your emotions and meditating
      even without great resolve you are still likely to rid yourself of a
      DSP. The downside to doing it that way is that DSPs have no
      permanence. It is almost like saying "Sure I can give in to Satan as
      long as I spend a sufficient amount of time repenting on Sunday in
      Church"...

      So now that I've typed that out, maybe it isn't such a great idea...

      Thoughts?

      | 2018|2007|2006-11-16 13:07:56|widderslainte|Re: Rules Questions|
      --- wrote:

      > I think that unless you take an aspect or a stunt for your
      > weapon/armor/lightsaber/etc etc it doesn't have any mechanical effect.
      > Beyond that of altering what skill you use in combat that is. For
      > example with a Lightsaber in my hand I can use my Lightsaber skill to
      > defend, but without it I'm using Athletics.

      So that would mean that if my Lightsaber is fair and my Melee is fair,
      there's not difference between hitting someone with a brick or with a
      lightsaber?

      > For DSP, one mechanic that we used on the fly last night was a Resolve
      > roll to convert a DSP into a LSP. If we decide we want to keep that
      > mechanic I feel that the base difficulty of that roll should be fairly
      > high, but if take steps up the time scale you get a bonus on the roll.

      > night.

      guessing we want one.

      | 2019|2007|2006-11-16 14:36:30|David Beebe|Re: Rules Questions|
      My guess is there's no difference in hitting a mook with a brick vs hitting with a lightsaber. (though you could very easily add +1 to a lightsaber and I don't think anybody would complain) You actually could do something specifically with lightsaber where your force rank (initiate, paduwan, knight, master) translates to larger numbers
       
      initiate +1
      paduwan +2
      Knight +3
      master +4
       
      with those number diminishing if you're dealing with bigger badguys. (with the number never going negative)
       
      mook (base)
      named mook (-1) Ensign Piet/ Vorksyr
      captain (-2)
      general (-3) (boba Fett)
      named anti-hero (-4) (Darth Vader)
       
      So a paduwan could face off against (skill) + 2 against mooks but would be at (skill) 0 against Darth Vader
      So rolling exceptionally well with a great skill a paduwan wiht a light saber could kill 10 mooks in a round. (with editorial liscence to kick over at least two of them and force push two against the wall)
       
      you're jedi afterall!

       
       
      On 11/16/06, widderslainte <widderslainte@comcast.net> wrote:

      --- wrote:

      > I think that unless you take an aspect or a stunt for your
      > weapon/armor/lightsaber/etc etc it doesn't have any mechanical effect.
      > Beyond that of altering what skill you use in combat that is. For
      > example with a Lightsaber in my hand I can use my Lightsaber skill to
      > defend, but without it I'm using Athletics.

      So that would mean that if my Lightsaber is fair and my Melee is fair,
      there's not difference between hitting someone with a brick or with a
      lightsaber?

      > For DSP, one mechanic that we used on the fly last night was a Resolve
      > roll to convert a DSP into a LSP. If we decide we want to keep that
      > mechanic I feel that the base difficulty of that roll should be fairly
      > high, but if take steps up the time scale you get a bonus on the roll.
      > The time scale was on that handy little cheat sheet Nate had last

      guessing we want one.

      widderslainte@comcast.net


      | 2020|2007|2006-11-16 14:36:56|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Rules Questions|
      > So that would mean that if my Lightsaber is fair and
      > my Melee is fair,
      > there's not difference between hitting someone with
      > a brick or with a
      > lightsaber?

      Per standard SotC rules weapons and armor don't give
      you bonuses unless you've added traits to them through
      stunts. The benefit of Guns is that it allows you to
      attack at a distance, but you can't defend with your
      Guns skill. Fists allows you to both attack and
      defend.

      However I think Lightsabers can't be defended with
      Melee, only with Athletics (dodge) or Lightsaber
      (block).

      > Right now, I don't see a downside to getting dark
      > side points. I'm
      > guessing we want one.

      Agreed. I've got a proot-mechanic in my head. Let me
      see if I can hammer it out and I'll post it.



      ____________________________________________________________________________________
      Sponsored Link

      Compare mortgage rates for today.
      Get up to 5 free quotes.
      Www2.nextag.com
      | 2021|2007|2006-11-16 14:52:10|Nathaniel Bennett|Lightsabers (was Rules Questions)|
      No way do I want to make that kind of calculation
      during battles!

      Lets break it down...what are the important
      characterstics of lightsabers? For argument's sake
      lets call them Aspects.

      Cut Through Nearly Anything
      Difficult to Use if You're Not Force-Sensitive

      What else should we add?




      ____________________________________________________________________________________
      Sponsored Link

      Mortgage rates near 39yr lows.
      $510k for $1,698/mo. Calculate new payment!
      www.LowerMyBills.com/lre
      | 2022|2007|2006-11-16 14:52:11|widderslainte|Re: Rules Questions|
      Nathaniel Bennett wrote:
      >
      > Per standard SotC rules weapons and armor don't give
      > you bonuses unless you've added traits to them through
      > stunts. The benefit of Guns is that it allows you to
      > attack at a distance, but you can't defend with your
      > Guns skill. Fists allows you to both attack and
      > defend.
      >
      > However I think Lightsabers can't be defended with
      > Melee, only with Athletics (dodge) or Lightsaber
      > (block).

      Gotcha. But excluding stunts, Lightsaber (good) vs Athletics/Dodge
      (fair) has the same mechanical effects as Melee/Brick (good) vs
      Athletics/Dodge (fair)?

      Through prerequisites and stunt slimming down, I ended up very combat
      oriented, and I want to figure out if I taking skill levels and stunts
      for dramatic effect or for combat effectiveness.

      --
      -------------------------
      widderslainte@comcast.net
      | 2023|2006|2006-11-16 16:09:54|David Beebe|Re: Advancement?|
      I'm in favor of an increase in stunts. (they are the 'cool' things we can throw around that add flavor)

      On 11/15/06, --- <oronisk@gmail.com> wrote:
      >  I've been thinking more about Advancement and power
      >  levels and I'd rather start play with three Stunts as
      >  opposed to Five. I think I mentioned this last week
      >  but I'm don't remember what y'all thought of it. Would
      >  any character be crippled with only three stunts to
      >  start?
      >
      >  SotC recommends half as many Stunts as Aspects, so my
      >  proposed Advancement Scheme is...
      >
      >  Skill
      >  Skill
      >  Skill
      >  Skill & Aspect
      >  Skill
      >  Skill
      >  Skill
      >  Skill, Aspect & Stunt
      >  Lather, Rinse Repeat.


      So coming from a background of D&D I'm used to getting experience
      points every session. I didn't get the impression that we would be
      getting a skill point every session we played for this game. However,
      if we only get one skill point for each completed story arc then I
      believe advancement will be incredibly slow. At that rate we would
      only gain one or two new stunts over the course of one whole year of
      real life.

      I guess the question is where is the balance?

      What do you all think? Is my sense of the rate of advancement way off?

      ~Logan

      | 2024|2024|2006-11-16 21:33:17|---|SW Dark Times - Next Session Tuesday 11/21|

      Which I have now cleared in favor of our group.

      someone speaks up?

      Cheers,
      Logan
      | 2025|2025|2006-11-16 21:34:37|---|SW Dark Times - Extra Weekend Gaming|
      I think I pitched this idea after two of you had left Wednesday so I'm
      putting it up here...

      I thought it would be fun to have the occasional weekend marathon for
      our group. Since on the tail end of Thanksgiving we have Christmas
      having one soon may be unlikely. However, I thought it would at least
      give people a chance to look at their calendars and see what we can
      come up with.

      Cheers,
      Logan

      | 2034|2034|2006-11-19 15:53:35|---|Force Cheat Sheet - Rough Draft|
      Attachments :
        Here is a rough draft of the force cheat sheet for someone with a
        "Good" Force Ability.

        Basically you can get a +1 for a "force usage" mark or a +2 for a force point.

        Let me know what you guys think. I'll make whatever changes we think
        are needed and then draft up one for Fair as well. Then I can make the
        other levels as needed.

        One thing I came to realize while making this sheet is that there are
        multiple ways to accomplish some things. A naturally strong character
        can complement his strength with Control whereas a weak character who
        is strong with the force can use Alter and accomplish the same thing.

        Also, I made this in WordPerfect and I do not have Microsoft Office on
        my computer, so I have no idea what the .doc will look like. Not all
        of my formatting showed up in the PDF.

        Cheers,
        Logan

        | 2042|2042|2006-11-21 10:48:31|Nathaniel Bennett|What kind of player are you?|
        http://quizfarm.com/test2.php?q_id=275080

        I scored 80% Character Player and 75% Storyteller.

        You scored as Character Player.

        The Character Player enjoys creating in-depth
        characters with distinct and rich personalities. He
        identifies closely with his characters, feeling
        detached from the game if he doesnt. He takes
        creative pride in exploring different characters,
        often making each new one radically different than
        others hes played. The Character Player bases his
        decisions on his character's psychology first and
        foremost. He may view rules as a necessary evil at
        best, preferring sessions in which the dice never come
        out of their bags. For the Character Player, the
        greatest reward comes from experiencing the game from
        the emotional perspective of an interesting character.

        You scored as Storyteller.

        The Storyteller is in it for the plot: the sense of
        mystery and the fun of participating in a narrative
        that has the satisfying arc of a good book or movie.
        He enjoys interacting with well-defined NPCs, even
        preferring antagonists who have genuine motivations
        and personality to mere monsters. To the Storyteller,
        the greatest reward of the game is participating in a
        compelling story with interesting and unpredictable
        plot threads, in which his actions and those of his
        fellow characters determine the resolution. With
        apologies to Robin Laws.



        ____________________________________________________________________________________

        Online degrees - find the right program to advance your career.
        www.nextag.com

        --- On Tue 11/21, Nathaniel Bennett < nathaniel_bennett@yahoo.com > wrote:

        http://quizfarm.com/test2.php?q_id=275080

        I scored 80% Character Player and 75% Storyteller.

        You scored as Character Player.

        The Character Player enjoys creating in-depth
        characters with distinct and rich personalities. He
        identifies closely with his characters, feeling
        detached from the game if he doesn�t. He takes
        creative pride in exploring different characters,
        often making each new one radically different than
        others he�s played. The Character Player bases his
        decisions on his character's psychology first and
        foremost. He may view rules as a necessary evil at
        best, preferring sessions in which the dice never come
        out of their bags. For the Character Player, the
        greatest reward comes from experiencing the game from
        the emotional perspective of an interesting character.

        You scored as Storyteller.

        The Storyteller is in it for the plot: the sense of
        mystery and the fun of participating in a narrative
        that has the satisfying arc of a good book or movie.
        He enjoys interacting with well-defined NPCs, even
        preferring antagonists who have genuine motivations
        and personality to mere monsters. To the Storyteller,
        the greatest reward of the game is participating in a
        compelling story with interesting and unpredictable
        plot threads, in which his actions and those of his
        fellow characters determine the resolution. With
        apologies to Robin Laws.

        | 2053|2050|2006-11-28 16:20:20|David Beebe|Re: Force Points mechanics|
        You will know when you are at rest, when your mind is clear -Yoda
         
        DSP count against your Force Point Refresh rate.
        (so if you get 5 force points at refresh, if you have 2 dark side points, you only will get 3 at refresh)
         
        DSP spent on selfish things result in retaining the DSP and maybe getting another one. (?)
        heroic things and long term mediation can switch them from DSP to LSP.
         
         
        Suggestion:
        DSP when spent for things like camera control, or changes to the scene result in temporary negative aspects.
         
        (palpatine's super gaunt face after spending a DSP to compel anakin's aspect "whiney bitch who loves a purdy girl")

        mechanics last week?

        | 2058|2045|2006-11-28 19:07:20|Mark Simpson|Re: group tactics|
        >>>>> "David" == David Beebe <thedavidbeebe@gmail.com> writes:

        David> Well I hadn't thought of it in that light! Kolton is our
        David> strongest gunner, (and he usually goes first) I'm wondering
        David> if it makes sense for him to hold, so that I can either
        David> leadership us up a tactical bonus or use a ''rain of
        David> blaster fire" (or a swish swish of vibro tekanique) to
        David> manuever someone to a disadvantage

        Sounds like a good idea. My character might decide to start shooting
        too quickly (and just what problems CAN'T be solved by guns?!) so in some
        circumstances Kolton could hol his action until after your character
        (or whoever was next) acted. I'd say your character should give a
        quick warning shout to Kolton if he doesn't want Kolton to just go
        ahead with whatver _he_ thinks is a good idea.

        In general my character, when in some sort of combat, will be acting
        from some sort of distance if possible; all the rest of the
        characters, being swordsbeings will be acting at shorter distance.

        Akidan is definately very lightsaber oriented... but just how is Prahl
        oriented combat wise? Seems to be more acrobatic?
        | 2059|2045|2006-11-28 20:04:51|David Beebe|Re: group tactics|

        | 2081|2081|2006-12-04 10:22:07|Nathaniel Bennett|Troupe style|
        One of the goals with Dark Times is to make it a
        troupe style game so that when I need a break from
        GMing other people can step in and take the reins
        while maintaining campaign continutity. Shawn, Logan,
        and David have all expressed interest in running Dark
        Times stories so I wanted to find out who is inspired
        to step to the plate first. I don't expect to have
        completed my story arc for at least a month or two,
        but I know I like prep time so I thought I'd start the
        ball rolling. Also I'm going to want to work with the
        next GM on my character.



        ____________________________________________________________________________________
        Have a burning question?
        Go to www.Answers.yahoo.com and get answers from real people who know.

        | 2089|2089|2006-12-08 09:13:42|Nathaniel Bennett|HoloNet news stories|
         The Declaration of a New Order was a proclamation
        made by Supreme Chancellor Palpatine first as an
        address to an Extraordinary Session of the Galactic
        Senate and then to the general populace. In it, he
        proclaimed himself Emperor of the Galaxy, revealed the
        treason of the Jedi Order, and outlined his vision of
        transforming the thenceforth-abolished Galactic
        Republic into the new Galactic Empire.

         Jedi Rebellion, the attempt by the Jedi Order to
        overthrow the Palpatine Government and replace it with
        a Force-worshiping theocracy. Across the galaxy
        treasonous Jedi and their allies worked against the
        people and their lawful Government, including a Jedi
        attempt to assassinate Palpatine himself under the
        pretext that that Palpatine wouldnt immediately step
        down when the Jedi declared that the war was over with
        Grievous death, rather than waiting to see if the
        fighting was actually going to end. Information
        gathered from the Jedi Archives proves that the Jedi
        Order itself engineered the Clone Wars. Separatist
        leader Count Dooku acted on orders from the Jedi
        Council and it was Jedi Master Sifo-Dyas who ordered
        the creation of the Republics clone army. The Jedi
        ordered the clone troopers of the Grand Army to be
        short-lived because the Jedi wouldnt need them once
        they had overthrown the Palpatine Government. The plot
        of the Jedi was foiled by Emperor Palpatine and the
        clone troops which proved to be loyal to the
        Government and not their Jedi overlords by executing
        Executive Order 66. The Order branded the Jedi as
        traitors and called for their immediate execution
        without question.

         COMPOR (the Commission for the Preservation of the
        Republic) has been replaced by a new organization,
        COMPNOR (the Commission for the Preservation of the
        New Order).

         63 Senators have been arrested on charges of
        conspiracy and treason in the wake of the "Jedi
        rebellion." At this time, the latest names added to
        the list of traitors are Ivor Drake of Kestos Minor,
        Streamdrinker of Tynna, Shea, Sadashassa of Herdessa,
        Tanner Cadaman of Fennix, Grebleips of Brodo Asagi,
        and Fang Zhar of Sern Prime.

         The Trade Federation, under Acting Viceroy Sentepeth
        Findos, has been nationalized as part of the Empire.

         The new regional governors, Moffs, who will now be a
        direct link between various sectors and the Emperor
        himself. Among the first Moffs announced to the public
        are Wilhufff Tarkin, Denn Wessex, and Marcellin
        Wessel.

         Citizens are urged to register their names,
        political persuasion, and weapons with Imperial
        authorities for the greater good.

         Citizens are urged to help the new Empire by being
        clone donors, joining the military, joining COMPNOR,
        and becoming "eyes" for the Empire.

         Non-human residents of the Empire are urged to
        register with their local Imperial representative.

         Jedi fugitives still at large include Kai Justiss,
        Halagad Ventor, Qu Rahn, Ydra Kiwallen, Maw the
        Boltrunian, and Ranik Solusar.

         The Senate Rotunda has been closed to repair damage
        caused by Jedi Master Yoda in his failed attempt to
        assassinate the Emperor.

         It is against Imperial law to salvage from the
        wreckage of the Battle of Coruscant.

         An industrial accident has reduced refining capacity
        in the Mustafar system resulting in a price increase
        for dolovite to 760 credits per barrel.

         This year's Caamasi "Rainbow of Sunshine" Festival
        has been cancelled.




        ____________________________________________________________________________________
        Yahoo! Music Unlimited
        Access over 1 million songs.
        http://music.yahoo.com/unlimited
        | 2090|2090|2006-12-08 09:17:53|Nathaniel Bennett|The Declaration of a New Order|
        The Declaration of a New Order was a proclamation made
        by Supreme Chancellor Palpatine first as an address to
        an Extraordinary Session of the Galactic Senate and
        then to the general populace. The anniversary of the
        Declaration's issue will henceforth be celebrated as
        Empire Day.

        The full text:

        "Citizens of the civilized Galaxy, on this day we mark
        a transition. For a thousand years, the Republic stood
        as the crowning achievement of civilized beings. But
        there were those who would set us against one another,
        and we took up arms to defend our way of life against
        the Separatists. In so doing, we never suspected that
        the greatest threat came from within.

        The Jedi, and some within our own Senate, had
        conspired to create the shadow of Separatism using one
        of their own as the enemy's leader. They had hoped to
        grind the Republic into ruin. But the hatred in their
        hearts could not be hidden forever. At last, there
        came a day when our enemies showed their true natures.

        The Jedi hoped to unleash their destructive power
        against the Republic by assassinating the head of
        government and usurping control of the clone army. But
        the aims of would-be tyrants were valiantly opposed by
        those without elitist, dangerous powers. Our loyal
        clone troopers contained the insurrection within the
        Jedi Temple and quelled uprisings on a thousand
        worlds.

        The remaining Jedi will be hunted down and defeated.
        Any collaborators will suffer the same fate. These
        have been trying times, but we have passed the test.
        The attempt on my life has left me scarred and
        deformed, but I assure you my resolve has never been
        stronger. The war is over. The Separatists have been
        defeated, and the Jedi rebellion has been foiled. We
        stand on the threshold of a new beginning. In order to
        ensure our security and continuing stability, the
        Republic will be reorganized into the first Galactic
        Empire, for a safe and secure society, which I assure
        you will last for ten thousand years. An Empire that
        will continue to be ruled by this august body and a
        sovereign ruler chosen for life. An Empire ruled by
        the majority, ruled by a new constitution.

        By bringing the entire Galaxy under one law, one
        language, and the enlightened guidance of one
        individual, the corruption that plagued the Republic
        in its later years will never take root. Regional
        governors will eliminate the bureaucracy that allowed
        the Separatist movement to grow unchecked. A strong
        and growing military will ensure the rule of law.

        Under the Empire's New Order, our most cherished
        beliefs will be safeguarded. We will defend our ideals
        by force of arms. We will give no ground to our
        enemies and will stand together against attacks from
        within or without. Let the enemies of the Empire take
        heed: those who challenge Imperial resolve will be
        crushed.

        We have taken on a task that will be difficult, but
        the people of the Empire are ready for the challenge.
        Because of our efforts, the galaxy has traded war for
        peace and anarchy for stability. Billions of beings
        now look forward to a secure future. The Empire will
        grow as more planets feel the call, from the Rim to
        the wilds of unknown space.

        Imperial citizens must do their part. Join our grand
        star fleet. Become the eyes of the Empire by reporting
        suspected insurrectionists. Travel to the corners of
        the Galaxy to spread the principles of the New Order
        to barbarians. Build monuments and technical wonders
        that will speak of our glory for generations to come.

        The clone troopers, now proudly wearing the name of
        Imperial stormtroopers, have tackled the dangerous
        work of fighting out enemies on the front lines. Many
        have died in their devotion to the Empire. Imperial
        citizens would do well to remember their example.

        The New Order of peace has triumphed over the shadowy
        secrecy of shameful magicians. The direction of our
        course is clear. I will lead the Empire to glories
        beyond imagining.

        We have been tested, but we have emerged stronger. We
        move forward as one people: the Imperial citizens of
        the first Galactic Empire. We will prevail. Ten
        thousand years of peace begins today."




        ____________________________________________________________________________________
        Any questions? Get answers on any topic at www.Answers.yahoo.com. Try it now.
        | 2091|2091|2006-12-08 10:56:15|Nathaniel Bennett|The Plan & Goals|
        Since I need to plan two plus sessions for next week
        it would be helpful to have an email discussion about
        yoru character's plans so that I can prep.

        As I understand it the plan as it stands now is to
        unburden yourselves from your dependents and find out
        WTF is going on in the galaxy. The first part is risky
        but seemingly straightforward - you drop the Senator
        off in the Cophrigin System and then take Kerrado home
        to papa on Nar Shadda.

        However I'm not sure what your plan is about finding
        somewhere to drop the younglings or how you plan to
        find other jedi and get a grip on the Jedi Apocalypse
        that happened while it was sleepy time.

        The Galaxy is a big place and the Jedi have been
        around for 10,000 years. As such they have a major
        infrastructure throughout the Galaxy. However most of
        that was paid for by the Republic which means its
        matter of public record. However the size and age of
        the Jedi Order means there are places that are off the
        beaten path like the Jedi Temple on the ice world from
        the Clone Wars animated series. Rather then try and
        research very Jedi outpost in the expanded universe
        I'd rather you guys use your creativity and Force
        Points for dramatic editting. You want your character
        to know about a secret Jedi Temple? Spend a Force
        Point and make it so!

        Thoughts? Would a list of goals be useful?

        __________________________________________________

        | 2095|2091|2006-12-08 15:59:06|David Beebe|Re: The Plan & Goal|
        A long range jedi-sensor sweep of the galaxy
        In the Hapes Cluster, the planet of UT is know for is music and singing voices.    Everyone understands the basic concept of a auditorium? a place where a person can stand and sing and her voice is amplified to even the far back seats. This is done through a proper understanding of harmonics.  As... part of my honeymoon, I ... we... went to a performance.  It started with one voice. One singer. She was barely whispering. Another voice joined her, and another, and after that another.  In the end there were 15 women whispering a beautiful song.  It could be heard througout the auditorium. And than they raised the volume of thier voices. and it became almost deafening.
         
        What does this have to do with anything?
        My question is, "in much the same way that a song can be amplified, can the 'harmonics' of the jedi mediation be amplified to sense what is out there? to ... see how many more are out there that haven't been caught?"  I don't know how many prison ships they have. I dont' know if there are more Jedi cut-off in those energy bubbles. But I do know that you 'felt' Aura Sing in the next room. Can you... maybe together feel the jedi throughout the galaxy? Do you need names? Are all of the light sabers in the box that belonged to General Grevious those of dead jedi?  Maybe some still live?  If not the whole galaxy can you do this while we travel to the outer rim? We are starting in the core and moving to the rim. It gives a nice slice of the galaxy.
         
        A Hapan fable of political ambition (emporer Palpatine is just a man)
        Once there was an ambitious woman and her dynasty.  She wanted to be high queen mother, but she forgot to check all of her food for poison and one day she died strangely died in her sleep with a dagger between her breats. The end 
         
        a base of operations
        I think we should set up a base of operations that neither the hutt nor the senator know where we're going to set down. The sith were able to hide from the Jedi? how? Can we reverse that vision cloud to work in our favor? Can we hide in an old forgotten sith temple. (or near one)
         
        find a master (Master master mater, why why why)
        we need to continue the training of the younglings and you all need to continue your training (and you all will insist that i start training). mayhaps we can find one in our sweeps. of course if Yoda recorded a message it stands to reason that Yoda lives...
         
        rebuild the order (me me me... me too)
        It never did seem clear to me why the jedi council would order clones made of a bounty hunter and not clones of jedi. We have some able young jedi here. we could go to that cloner planet and raise up an army to fight this old army. of course we also have the brilliant mind of a sadistic and powerful tactician who was taught many things by sith, we could use him as a template if we could find a way of quashing the evil parts. (i'm just saying he was rumored to be a wizard with the ligthsaber)
         
         
         
        How important are 'the archives' ?(a darring raid on Coruscant...)
        if we're going to start re-building, do we need to go get us some of the datacrystals of information at the old temple?
         
        what's at those coordinates?
        or we could go deep into the core and find out what mystery is happening at the end of the 'rainbow'  You were being taken there, it would stand to reason that other jedi might be there. If they live yet, it might be a place to start a rescue. What could we possibly find out there besides some moon?
         
        Become a Knight get a paduwan of your very own... (minions for EVERYONE!)
        er so... what's the step to becoming a knight? Akibar mentioned he was almost one. Do you have to be knighted by someone?  my sister's journal mentioned some trials? 
         
        Options:
        get you guys knighted
        run and hide (like yoda said) - and try to rebuild the order with a rag tag group of 10 younglings and 3 knights
        go find yoda - and try to rebuild the order with a rag tag group of 10 younglings and 3 knights
        get info from Corusant
        go kill the emperor.
        go deep into the core
        clone us a jedi army
        clone us a grevious army (minus bad parts)
        (both of those plans require capital, maybe join the hutt's for a bit, or make a sports team, or become pirates.)
        set up a base.
        get a bigger ship for a moving base/temple
         
         
         
        On 12/8/06, Nathaniel Bennett <nathaniel_bennett@yahoo.com
        > wrote:

        Since I need to plan two plus sessions for next week
        it would be helpful to have an email discussion about
        yoru character's plans so that I can prep.

        As I understand it the plan as it stands now is to
        unburden yourselves from your dependents and find out
        WTF is going on in the galaxy. The first part is risky
        but seemingly straightforward - you drop the Senator
        off in the Cophrigin System and then take Kerrado home
        to papa on Nar Shadda.

        However I'm not sure what your plan is about finding
        somewhere to drop the younglings or how you plan to
        find other jedi and get a grip on the Jedi Apocalypse
        that happened while it was sleepy time.

        The Galaxy is a big place and the Jedi have been
        around for 10,000 years. As such they have a major
        infrastructure throughout the Galaxy. However most of
        that was paid for by the Republic which means its
        matter of public record. However the size and age of
        the Jedi Order means there are places that are off the
        beaten path like the Jedi Temple on the ice world from
        the Clone Wars animated series. Rather then try and
        research very Jedi outpost in the expanded universe
        I'd rather you guys use your creativity and Force
        Points for dramatic editting. You want your character
        to know about a secret Jedi Temple? Spend a Force
        Point and make it so!

        Thoughts? Would a list of goals be useful?

        | 2123|2123|2006-12-15 11:49:25|Nathaniel Bennett|Combat stunts idea|
        David, Logan and I kicked around some new mechanics
        ideas last night and then I had inspiration this
        morning. Rather then try and codify Lightsaber forms
        and martial arts styles with specific maneuvers and
        abilities I propose that we make them mini-Aspects
        which give you a +2 or reroll in a situation that
        pertains specifically to that skill.

        So for example if you specialize in Form III, the
        uber-defensive saber form then you could use your Form
        III stunt for a lightsaber move that you could explain
        as being part of your Form III training.

        I think this is both in the spirit of the rules and
        gives us the freedom to be cinematic and descriptive
        and have some mechanics to back it up. What do you
        guys think?

        __________________________________________________
        Do You Yahoo!?
        Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around
        http://mail.yahoo.com
        | 2124|2123|2006-12-15 12:21:59|---|Re: Combat stunts idea|
        So the forms would occupy a stunt slot, but work like an aspect (with the exception of not needing a fate point to activate them)?

        If I am understanding it, I really like that method.
        | 2125|2123|2006-12-15 12:46:51|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Combat stunts idea|
        --- --- <oronisk@gmail.com> wrote:

        > So the forms would occupy a stunt slot, but work
        > like an aspect (with the
        > exception of not needing a fate point to activate
        > them)?
        >
        > If I am understanding it, I really like that method.
        >

        Yes, though we'd need a limiting factor. Maybe taking
        the stunt once gives you the ability to tag the Stunt
        for free once per battle. Taking it again gives you
        Mastery which allows you to tag it free twice?

        | 2130|2123|2006-12-15 14:39:58|---|Re: Combat stunts idea|
        Most stunts on SotC only provide one functionality. All of the
        Lightsaber stunts provide multiple things, but you have to spend
        something for most of them.

        Why not combine the two?

        Our versions of the combat stunts could provide a minor +1 bonus to
        some activity or situation for free and you can get a +2 bonus by
        explaining it appropriately and spending a Force Point (or whatever we
        decide to spend).

        Basically an aspect and stunt wrapped into one stunt.

        That make sense?
        | 2131|2123|2006-12-15 14:52:04|widderslainte|Re: Combat stunts idea|
        --- wrote:
        > Most stunts on SotC only provide one functionality. All of the
        > Lightsaber stunts provide multiple things, but you have to spend
        > something for most of them.
        >
        > Why not combine the two?
        >
        > Our versions of the combat stunts could provide a minor +1 bonus to
        > some activity or situation for free and you can get a +2 bonus by
        > explaining it appropriately and spending a Force Point (or whatever we
        > decide to spend).
        >
        > Basically an aspect and stunt wrapped into one stunt.
        >
        > That make sense?

        Form I lets you do this:

        * Maneuver: May spend a Force Point to gain free supplemental action
        (cannot be attack action) once per Exchange.
        * Maneuver: May spend a Force Point in conjunction with Spin on a Full
        Defense action to reflect blaster fire back toward a single blaster
        wielding opponent (or minion group) as a supplemental attack action,
        once per Exchange.

        How does it work with the new stunt?

        --
        -------------------------
        widderslainte@comcast.net

        Excellent, everyone's good.

        Homework for Thursday:

        Aspects: make sure you have six. I have no problem
        with changing Aspects on the fly, but I'd like
        everyone to have at least something written down for
        all six.

        Outfit: The Mist Stalker has a well appointed wardrobe
        which has allowed the characters to change out of
        their jedi robes if they'd like to be a little less
        obvious. Coming to Thursday's game with a description
        of what your character now wears is worth an FP for
        the session.

        | 2184|2184|2007-01-12 09:00:35|Nathaniel Bennett|Questions answered|
        Jastus Farr was likely a Tarro.
        http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Tarro

        Lightstaff is another name for double-bladed
        lightsabers. However one of the early Jedi
        weaponmasters used a traditional staff instead of a
        lightsaber or lightstaff, and was known to be one of
        the greatest duelists in Jedi history.



        ____________________________________________________________________________________

        Try the Yahoo! Mail Beta.
        http://advision.webevents.yahoo.com/mailbeta/newmail_tools.html

        night's session? I'll try to correlate everything into a legible form.

        | 2191|2189|2007-01-12 15:14:00|David Beebe|Re: Last Night's Session|

        On 1/12/07, Nathaniel Bennett <nathaniel_bennett@yahoo.com> wrote:

        | 2192|2189|2007-01-12 16:05:55|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Last Night's Session|
        Arrive at Kessel
        Hailed by Space Control and told to bugger off
        Investigate the planet and discover Jedi beacon on far
        side from main city
        Beacon leads to abandoned mining outpost
        Motley collection of ships on the outposts landing
        platform
        Mist Stalker does sweep and finds a few other ships
        tucked away beneath the landing platform.
        Mist stalker lands on landing platform, drops PCs and
        dusts off
        PCs enter abandoned mining facility via airlock and
        can hear voices ahead.
        Met in the corridor by Jedi Master Shadday Potkin, who
        called the Conclave
        Master Shadday brings them into the main mining
        chamber and introduces them to the attendees:
        Master Koffi Arana, human
        Master Tsui Choi, alee
        Master Jastus Farr, torr
        Master Makis, kajain
        Master Obi-Wan Kenobi, human and member of Jedi
        Council
        Padawan Sia-Lan Wezz, human
        After introductions are made the Conclave comes to
        order and various strategies for dealing with the
        crisis are discussed. The positions of each Conclave
        member:
        Jastus Farr: Rebuild Jedi Order and reactivate
        Separatist droid armies
        Koffi Arana: Locate and assassinate Darth Sidious
        before the New Sith Empire consolidates its power, the
        Dark Side has proven more powerful
        Mikas: Leave the known galaxy entirely
        Kenobi: Follow Master Yodas instructions and go into
        hiding, waiting for the time when the Force recalls
        the Jedi to defend the true Chosen One (not Anakin
        Skywalker but someone related him who Kenobi is
        guarding).
        Tsui Choi: Cant turn back on Galaxy, must join
        rebellious Senators and fight the Empire
        Kenobi asked Shadday what she expected when she called
        the Conclave, and she responded:
        Shadday: I expected that we Jedi would do as we always
        do. We would gather and examine the idea, talk it
        through, think about it, perhaps mediate on it. And
        nothing would be done. Or, if done we would act too
        late to matter. Which is why I made my final
        invitation.
        Obi: Master Shadday, what have you done?
        Shadday: Reach out with your feelings, Master Kenobi.
        The tunnels shield his approach but I know you can
        feel him now. I have heard through my contacts that
        the Emperors enforcer, Darth Vader, seeks your
        whereabouts. I leaked word that you would be here. I
        do not know the reason for Vaders hatred of you. I
        only know that it draws him here. However powerful
        Vader is he is one and we are many. No more debate. No
        more reflection. No need to plan. Our prey comes to
        us.
        When he is dead the Emperor will be crippled and the
        galaxy will know the Jedi have survived.
        Enter Darth Vader.




        ____________________________________________________________________________________

        http://advision.webevents.yahoo.com/mailbeta/features_spam.html

        Session 5: Cophrigin V (12/14/06


         
        On 1/12/07, Nathaniel Bennett <nathaniel_bennett@yahoo.com> wrote:

        Arrive at Kessel
        Hailed by Space Control and told to bugger off
        Investigate the planet and discover Jedi beacon on far
        side from main city
        Beacon leads to abandoned mining outpost
        Motley collection of ships on the outpost's landing
        platform
        Mist Stalker does sweep and finds a few other ships
        tucked away beneath the landing platform.
        Mist stalker lands on landing platform, drops PCs and
        dusts off
        PCs enter abandoned mining facility via airlock and
        can hear voices ahead.
        Met in the corridor by Jedi Master Shadday Potkin, who
        called the Conclave
        Master Shadday brings them into the main mining
        chamber and introduces them to the attendees:
        Master Koffi Arana, human
        Master Tsui Choi, alee
        Master Jastus Farr, torr
        Master Ma'kis, kajain
        Master Obi-Wan Kenobi, human and member of Jedi
        Council
        Padawan Sia-Lan Wezz, human
        After introductions are made the Conclave comes to
        order and various strategies for dealing with the
        crisis are discussed. The positions of each Conclave
        member:
        Jastus Farr: Rebuild Jedi Order and reactivate
        Separatist droid armies
        Koffi Arana: Locate and assassinate Darth Sidious
        before the New Sith Empire consolidates its power, the
        Dark Side has proven more powerful
        Mi'kas: Leave the known galaxy entirely
        Kenobi: Follow Master Yoda's instructions and go into
        hiding, waiting for the time when the Force recalls
        the Jedi to defend the true Chosen One (not Anakin
        Skywalker but someone related him who Kenobi is
        guarding).
        Tsui Choi: Can't turn back on Galaxy, must join
        rebellious Senators and fight the Empire
        Kenobi asked Shadday what she expected when she called
        the Conclave, and she responded:
        Shadday: I expected that we Jedi would do as we always
        do. We would gather and examine the idea, talk it
        through, think about it, perhaps mediate on it. And
        nothing would be done. Or, if done we would act too
        late to matter. Which is why I made my final
        invitation.
        Obi: Master Shadday, what have you done?
        Shadday: Reach out with your feelings, Master Kenobi.
        The tunnels shield his approach but I know you can
        feel him now. I have heard through my contacts that
        the Emperor's enforcer, Darth Vader, seeks your
        whereabouts. I leaked word that you would be here. I
        do not know the reason for Vader's hatred of you. I
        only know that it draws him here. However powerful
        Vader is he is one and we are many. No more debate. No
        more reflection. No need to plan. Our prey comes to
        us.
        When he is dead the Emperor will be crippled and the
        galaxy will know the Jedi have survived.
        Enter Darth Vader.
