        | 2198|2198|2007-01-22 12:55:17|David Beebe|assuming we survive the swarm of tie fighters and don't get caught |
        I'm going to assume that there will be a dogfight, and than we'll bug out and leave.  I figured if we have an idea as to where we are going, we should probably figure it out a little before hand so we can do one of those cool cross-fades to "the new location" where we can keep going with the story.
         
        The short range:
        A) Back to Dark Woman.
        -complete the 'return to me' portion of  light saber creation
        -drop off the younglings?
        -connect some vader puzzle problems
        -work out a deal with the senator to try to find the 'new seperatists'
         
        B) lose the fighters and star destroyer, with the intetion of returning to this planet (this is the daring plan where we look as if we escaped, and because of the fact that Vader has a vendetta against some insolent padawans who chopped of his arm, he follows us, and therefore leaves the planet with all the extra residual space ships there for us to do some crack detective work, and end up with a couple more ships for a rag tag fleet)
         
        -the spider sacks can be used as crystals
        -we might find more info out using some detective work
         
         
        C) the off the books Jedi safe house.
        -a 'safe' haven for the younglings who will grow fantastically bored with no master
        -we have grevous's ship which may have some answers of one kind or another.
         
        D) we're going to need repairs to the two ships so some 'out of the way' planet in Hutt space (tatoinee?)
        -through poetic liscence we could find the skywalker heir
         
         
        The long range:
        This also depends on where we want the story arc to take us
        A) raise a droid army by persuing Grevous and Senator teeks leads
         
        B) enspire the rebel alliance by causing some serious greif to some of the most loyal planets to this new Empire
         
        C) create a new 'on the run' Jedi Order by training the kids, and self training. (you learn karate from book?) (this includes the possible 'daring run on Courasount to reclaim knowledge from the jedi archives)
         
        D)Take the fight to Vader and the Emperor
         
        *****************************
         
         
         
        | 2199|2198|2007-01-22 14:57:19|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: assuming we survive the swarm of tie fighters and don't get cau|
        Awesome suggestions! A few notes from the GM...

        > -complete the 'return to me' portion of light saber
        > creation

        Akiban feels that he is close to attuning his new
        saber, and Kolton feels that with a few days of
        concerted effort he might be able to attune his saber.


        > C) the off the books Jedi safe house.

        This is the Jedi chapter house in the Taleraan system,
        which is a gas giant similar to Bespin. The atmosphere
        of Taleraan is a breathable oxygen/nitrogen mix, and
        the chapterhouse is built on a floating vegetation
        mat.

        > -through poetic liscence we could find the skywalker
        > heir

        How about you find Master Kenobi's "True Chosen One"
        through investigation and clever use of the Force?

        > C) create a new 'on the run' Jedi Order by training
        > the kids, and self
        > training. (you learn karate from book?) (this
        > includes the possible 'daring
        > run on Courasount to reclaim knowledge from the jedi
        > archives)

        In the not too distant past there was a Jedi temple
        located aboard a large ship. It was home to Jedi
        Masters, Knights and Padawans, and acted as a mobile
        Jedi training facility/embassy before it crashed.

        Finding fabulous fares is fun.

        http://farechase.yahoo.com/promo-generic-14795097
        | 2200|2200|2007-01-22 19:51:12|---|Adding another element to our game... 'Space!'|
        The Final Frontier....

        So I was thinking to myself about how Space is a large part of the
        Star Wars universe, but our group has chosen to have it play a minimal
        role so far. Largely in part because we aren't novel characters and it
        isn't the best when one person has the camera in exclusion to others
        for an extended period of time.

        Not every character in the movies contributes in the space scenes.
        However, if we want to we could each take a 'space' skill and then
        incorporate space into our game.

        As far as I can tell Engineering, Heavy Weapons, and Pilot comprise
        all you need to know about operating in space (and possibly Erudition
        with some stretching).

        I just wanted to throw the idea out there for everyone to consider.

        Cheers,
        Logan
        | 2201|2201|2007-01-22 19:54:43|---|Fwd: Spirit of the Century: Players Wanted!|

        Logan,

        Rats. :) Are you on the FateRPG Yahoo List? There's been a lot of
        stuff posted about Star Wars adaptions, but I don't recall seeing your
        name.

        I'd love to hear your thoughts on the basic system, since I haven't
        actually run it before, and the whole idea was a test run.

        David

        | 2206|2200|2007-01-23 10:19:17|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Adding another element to our game... 'Space!'|
        > Not every character in the movies contributes in the
        > space scenes.
        > However, if we want to we could each take a 'space'
        > skill and then
        > incorporate space into our game.

        This is a great idea if people like the idea of space
        battles being a part of the game. Vehicles are a big
        part of action/pulp and sci-fi so I'm all for it.

        Shawn's argument that he signed up to play Jedi and
        not spaceman is crap since most of the Jedi in the
        movies were also accomplished starfighter pilots.


        One interesting fact about the Mist Stalker is that it
        can dock several starfighter sized ships along its
        neck. So one possibility would be for each character
        to have their own ship to use in battle.

        | 2207|2200|2007-01-23 10:42:03|widderslainte|Re: Adding another element to our game... 'Space!'|
        Nathaniel Bennett wrote:
        > This is a great idea if people like the idea of space
        > battles being a part of the game. Vehicles are a big
        > part of action/pulp and sci-fi so I'm all for it.

        I'm for it. Sarcasm aside, my point was that I built a Jedi character.
        With skill pyramid, you can't just go "boom-boom-boom I've got a decent
        level in heavy weapons". I've already got an average score in Pilot.
        But it's going to take a half dozen skill points (and sessions) to get
        fair in Pilot and Heavy Weapons.

        > Shawn's argument that he signed up to play Jedi and
        > not spaceman is crap since Luke and Anakin
        > movies were also accomplished starfighter pilots.

        I corrected your typo ;)

        | 2209|2200|2007-01-23 11:41:20|widderslainte|Re: Adding another element to our game... 'Space!'|
        Nathaniel Bennett wrote:

        > Along those lines I think its fair to use the Pilot
        > skill for ship-based weapons. I don't think Luke had
        > spent points on Heavy Weapons when he jumped into the
        > Falcon's turret.

        Gotcha. Just pointing out that it will take 3 skill points to get
        people to "Fair" level in a given skill. I don't have any problems
        doing space combat, but rather recognizing that it will take a couple
        sessions before getting competency. What I'm not down with rearranging
        my existing (and already schizophrenic) skill pyramid to resemble
        Starbuck. I can't believe they made her into a cylon.

        >>> Shawn's argument that he signed up to play Jedi
        >> and
        >>> not spaceman is crap since Luke and Anakin
        >>> movies were also accomplished starfighter pilots.
        >> I corrected your typo ;)
        >
        > DO NOT make me go through the Wookiepedia and list all
        > the Jedi who were known to be accomplished pilots.

        do all sort of crazy stuff. But you see very little Jedi dog-fighting
        in the films beyond Luke and Anakin/Vader.

        widderslainte@comcast.net
        | 2210|2200|2007-01-23 11:57:16|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Adding another element to our game... 'Space!'|
        > Gotcha. Just pointing out that it will take 3 skill
        > points to get
        > people to "Fair" level in a given skill. I don't
        > have any problems
        > doing space combat, but rather recognizing that it
        > will take a couple
        > sessions before getting competency.

        Good point. So the considerations are a) Do the
        players want to add space combat as a major game
        element and b) is the story going in a direction in
        which it makes sense to pick up space combat skills?
        Which brings us back to the question of what kind of
        game do we want moving forward?

        What I'm not
        > down with rearranging
        > my existing (and already schizophrenic) skill
        > pyramid to resemble
        > Starbuck. I can't believe they made her into a
        > cylon.

        Are you frakking kidding me? You'd better be frakking
        kidding me.

        | 2211|2200|2007-01-23 12:20:37|David Beebe|Re: Adding another element to our game... 'Space!'|
        Ironically enough I was just talking to Nathaniel about ways to make the mist stalker more fun for everyone...
         
         Also we can do something where we have battlestations, where they can help (essentially) characters have options to try  'manuevers' that can append aspects to the ship (fluxuate the shields through different frequencies make us harder to hit, temporarily boost yaw/pitch/roll thursters to improve in dodge) things like that? 
         
        and it can be done through
        computers/electronics
        whatever it is that allows you to hotwire a door (though it will leave a mess)
        or if the gm is feeling up to it, intimidation and cohercion (as you try to sweet talk the onboard computer to do things)

        | 2216|2216|2007-01-29 15:32:18|David Beebe|trading with the locals|
        Trading with the locals
        Luckily for us, we have the great Demosthenese; a retired steward of an old family dynasty from the Hapes Clusters. There are certain aphids that grow on the underside of these large balloon leaves. They secret a sweet resin that can be distilled into a sweet wine Which we can use to trade with the locals for food and supplies.
         
        we can also make baskets out of the plants. (hooray Jedi monastery!)

          | 2234|2233|2007-02-04 08:14:09|David Beebe|Re: Chewbacca arrested for assault|
          can he used the chewbacca defense?

          On 2/3/07, Mark Simpson <damned@theworld.com> wrote:

          | 2258|2253|2007-02-21 14:43:02|David Beebe|Re: Star Wars Dark Times query on temporary location change|
          getting to David's house from Points East
           
          "Oak Terrace Condominiums"
           
          MassPike (I 90) West
          Exit 12 Rt 9 (this is the second exit past 128/95)
          Take Rt 9 East
          U-turn at 2nd Light (Temple Street)- you will see a stop and shop on your right
          After U-turn you will pass a gas station on your right.
          The Brick complex on your right is the Oak Terrace Condominiums
          There are three entrances into the complex, park anywhere along them.
          1323 is the building closer to Rt 9.
           
          Unit F1
          1323 Worcester Road, Framingham, MA
           
          cell 617 275 9811

            | 2260|2260|2007-02-23 11:52:58|Nathaniel Bennett|Session 12: The Palace of Gardulla the Elder|
            Excellent session last night. Good blend of RP and
            action. I've made some additions to the wiki including
            notes on Gardulla's Jedi Museum and the text from the
            opening crawl and scene with Palpatine and Vader. If
            someone could send a summary to the list for Shawn
            I'll post it to the wiki (its worth a FP for next
            session!)

            Opening crawl and scene:
            http://rpg.wikia.com/wiki/Session_12:_The_Palace_of_Gardulla_the_Elder

            Museum:
            http://rpg.wikia.com/wiki/Gardulla%27s_Jedi_Museum

            | 2261|2261|2007-02-23 12:57:49|---|psuedo summary|
            - Session opened with us at the entrance to Gardula's palace

            - Guards spoke in Huttese when we announced ourselves, but then switched into broken basic

            - They asked us to reveal and deposit our weapons, but we had no weapons of consequence (Mind Trick)...

            - Major Domo met us at the entrance and scanned us all telepathically while leading us to Gardula's Throne Room

            - Throne room had several tunnels leading off to the left and one giant tapestry to the right which we noticed was not covering a wall

            - Lobbed much flowery speech and deference and the arm of general grievous with a lightsaber in it to Gardula... seemed to make a good impression

            - twilek slave used untrained psychometry to confirm arm of general G

            - found out she had a museum, we wanted to see it, she agreed, gave us a guided tour, includeing details about each artifact... her knowledge of jedi as warriors is fairly accurate, but her concept of jedi as an order is way off, she sees them only as warriors

            - koltan offers to "read" several of the lightsabers in her museum case in exchange for season box holder tickets... gardula says she will think about it

            - on the way out koltan feels a guard die nearby... tells majordomo who becomes suspicious and then "touches" koltan (not in a sexual way but for enhanced telepathic contact)... majordomo seems unpleased by whatever he reads of koltan, tells us to leave

            - we offer assisstance and end up with a grand cinematic fight scene

            - koltan uses major dark side mojo to take out a security droid

            - someone has bombed their way into the museum and stolen the kilian ranger energy shield gauntlet

            - prahl and constantine rush out front to try and block the intruders escape, hop on a passing by gardula security forces' speeder

            - koltan rushes out of the bombed hole in the museum to find himself on one of the central towers

            - prahl/constantine use speeder to ascend to central tower where they believe they have spotted the criminal, constantine makes an impressive force leap covering the vast distance and grabs onto a pulley system that was being used to paint gardula's palace, ascending the tower at a rapid pace

            - all three heroes converge on a figure in mandalorian armor, prahl disarms his lightsaber, while constantine jumps on his back as the figure ignites his jetpack

            - prahl smashes the criminal into the wall causing his jetpack to go wildly out of control, while koltan destroys one of the jets with a well placed blaster shot

            - constantine and the criminal have a very out of control ride down towards the precipe, while prahl/koltan pursue on speeder

            - prahl spits into the wind.... (fires a netgun from the speeder while it is in a dive)

            - constantine/criminal struggle with lightstaff

            - constantine leaps off and catches himself midway down the precipe with a lightsaber into the cliff wall, while koltan catches the criminal on the hood of the speeder with some skillful vehicular action

            - prahl attempts to remove the criminal jetpack only to cause it to spew flaming fuel all over the place

            - criminal get ouf of backpack, sets bomb timer

            - koltan crashes speeder into bridge/land rigght in front of palace

            - constantine barely gets the exploding jetpack away in time

            - criminal runs off into the distance only to be picked up by a ship of transdoshan make, the heroes tag it with a jedi tracker



            i'm sure I missed some, so you guys can fill in wherever...
            | 2262|2262|2007-02-23 13:10:52|---|Jedi Rapper?|
            Just glance at the picture....

            http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Echuu_Shen-Jon
            | 2263|2263|2007-02-23 17:29:39|---|Psuedo Summary 2|
            - Met Soln (sp?), he was being held behind the large tapestry on the right hand wall in Gardula's Throne room in a very large cage setup as as solo domocile

            - Soln seemed cautious of the newcomers, despite Koltan's attempt at a "Jedi Force Ping Greeting"

            - Constantine asked for Soln's help in rebuilding the order, Soln said he was busy

            - Prahl attempted to Force Push a small object as the curtain closed, but was not quite as subtle as he hoped, Soln covered by Force pulling the object
            | 2264|2264|2007-02-25 23:58:32|Mark Simpson|This is what the characters need...|
            Attachments :
              A bitchin VAN!:

              http://www.flickr.com/photos/dennyt/403012715/
              | 2265|2265|2007-02-26 16:23:00|Nathaniel Bennett|Mechanics - Force Techniques|
              Something I'm noticing is that we're only using a few
              basic Force abilities. Jump, push/pull, basic Mind
              Trick. This might be a result of the encounters
              themselves, or it might be because we've got weak
              rules for the Force. So I've been thinking about ways
              to add Force crunch without adding lots of new rules.
              My current idea is to add the concept of Force
              Techniques.

              A Force Technique is a specific use of the Force the
              character has learned. Force Techniques cost 1/2 skill
              point each and require the player to spend a Force
              Point to activate (or two if the stunt normally
              requires an FP). Force Techniques mimic existing
              Spirit of the Century stunts. Characters would gain a
              few basic force techniques through their Jedi
              training, and would then have to learn the rest
              through play. SotC stunts which have pre-reqs would
              require the same stunt as a Force Technique pre-req.
              So for example "Face the Pain" (an Endurance stunt)
              requires the stunt "Feel the Burn". A Jedi character
              would need the Force Technique "Feel the Burn" before
              they could take "Face the Pain".

              Sadly there's no easy to use list of stunts available
              so here's the list of skills which you can use stunts
              as Force Techniques. In some cases not all stunts
              would make sense as Force Techniques (eg Vehicles):

              Athletics
              Awareness
              Coercion
              Deftness
              Empathy
              Endurance
              Prowess
              Rapport
              Resolve
              Search
              Stealth
              Survival
              Vehicles

              Characters may still buy the stunts normally and use
              them normally (ie without spending a Force Point to
              use it as a Force Technique).

              Thoughts?



              ____________________________________________________________________________________
              8:00? 8:25? 8:40? Find a flick in no time
              with the Yahoo! Search movie showtime shortcut.
              http://tools.search.yahoo.com/shortcuts/#news
              | 2266|2265|2007-02-26 17:28:11|widderslainte|Re: Mechanics - Force Techniques|
              Nathaniel Bennett wrote:
              > Something I'm noticing is that we're only using a few
              > basic Force abilities. Jump, push/pull, basic Mind
              > Trick. This might be a result of the encounters
              > themselves, or it might be because we've got weak
              > rules for the Force. So I've been thinking about ways
              > to add Force crunch without adding lots of new rules.
              > My current idea is to add the concept of Force
              > Techniques.

              The Force rules are awkwardly laid out. Body/Project/Mind complement
              different abilities at different levels of Force skill, if you spend a
              tick. It's hard to keep track of without spend 5 minutes during your
              action skimming through it (oh, wait, my athletics is better than my
              force). Other stuff like "They may spend a Force Point for +2 on any
              single Endurance or Deftness test, once per Scene" isn't as useful when
              you have a Jedi aspect to two you can invoke under most of the same
              circumstances.

              There's plenty of stuff we're missing. I suspect most of use have a
              rough idea of what we should be able to do and spend point/make rolls to
              try to get it to happen. Stuff like "May spend a Force Point to use
              their Force Ability in place of any associated Ability test, once per
              Scene" could be cool, if you remember you can do it, and even then with
              the nature of the skill pyramid, it's probably about the same dice
              probability as somehow using a force point with a normal roll on the skill.

              > Characters may still buy the stunts normally and use
              > them normally (ie without spending a Force Point to
              > use it as a Force Technique).
              >
              > Thoughts?

              The concept is cool, but with the list of stunts may remain unwieldy.
              On top of that, it's not like we've got stunts to burn (in case of prereqs).

              We have the following to describe what we can do and how well:
              * Force stunts
              * Force skills (force, lightsaber at least)
              * Force-related aspects

              We've got force points as currency to limit how often we can do stuff.
              I think the more subsystems we add, the more it detracts from the point
              of investing in a "force skill".

              Perhaps we should start by making a list of "what jedi can do" and go
              from there.




              --
              -------------------------
              widderslainte@comcast.net

              | 2271|2267|2007-02-27 09:54:20|Mark Simpson|Re: Location?|
              On 2/27/07, Nathaniel Bennett <nathaniel_bennett@yahoo.com> wrote:
              > I added Mark directly in case he's not getting email
              > from Uod again.

              | 2272|2272|2007-02-27 22:40:48|---|Silly Lightsaber Form Quiz|
              Logan scored.....


              You scored as Form VII: Juyo/ Vaapaad.

              Dubbed the "Way of the Vornskr," Form VII was an incomplete form for
              millennia. It was further developed by Jedi Master Mace Windu, who
              could complete it with his, "Vaapaad" style. The most challenging and
              demanding of all forms, Form VII requires extreme, intense focus, high
              levels of skill, and mastery of other forms. Only two Jedi have ever
              mastered Form VII fully, Mace Windu and Depa Billaba. One other Jedi,
              Sora Bulq, mastered its physical aspects but was overwhelmed by the
              required mental discipline. Form VII, when fully mastered, results in
              extraordinary power.

              Form VII: Juyo/ Vaapaad 86%
              Form IV: Ataru 67%
              Form II: Makashi 50%
              Form III: Soresu 47%
              Form VI: Niman 33%
              Form V: Shien 19%





              Here is the quiz.... http://quizfarm.com/test.php?q_id=23485

              | 2275|2275|2007-03-01 12:52:32|David Beebe|jedi powers|
              did we get anywhere with that?
               
              Shawn mentioned coming up with a list of "what a jedi can do"
               
              http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Force_powers
               
              (the base list is pretty small)
              the extra list needs some of the more corny stuff culled out of it.
              | 2276|2276|2007-03-02 09:39:13|David Beebe|Rules re-vamp minutes (sent to four email acounts and maybe the uod|
              (I've decided to put this all in a google doc so we can correct and update it)
               
              Techniques:
              one-half skill point purchases the first tier of a technique. (known issue: this can slowly chip away at a character's pyramid)
               
              Maximum number of techniques
              The maximum techniques you can have are your current force skill rating x4
               
              Techniques are both
              • Light saber forms
              • Jedi Force abilities that can be simulated through the SOTC Stunts list
              • (optional other training things: this was built in in for future flexibility)
              Higher tier techniques are purchased through stunt expenditures
              (for example:
              spend one-half skill point to get tier 1 (basic) Form II (dueling) lightsaber,
              spend a stunt to get to Tier 2 (master) Form II (dueling) lightsaber,
              spend another stunt to get to Tier 3 (Grand Master) Form II (dueling))
               
              The light saber forms
              Your base skill is calculated from your "Lightsaber" skill
              At the start of combat round (when it is your turn) you declare your stance the stance confers an active bonus
              At Tier 2 or greater (master, grand master) you also receive a carry-over bonus which stacks with whatever different form you are in.
              You must also meet any pre-requisite skills in a particular form (for example Form II (the dueling form) requires Deftness at varying levels)
               
              Ask Logan or Nathaniel to add you as a collaborator to the google spreadsheet:
              Lightsaber Forms v4
               
              Force Powers from Techniques (Cost)
              Force powers will cost force ticks to activate.
              Some force powers will cost force points to activate (this will be case by case as we expand the powers list)
              Optional: depending on your force skill, this may offset the cost of different abilities
              Optional: depending on the tier mastery, this may offset the cost of different abilities
               
              Some Base Jedi Force abilities (can swap force in for a lesser skill)
              You can use your force skill to replace a weak skill.
              If you have no skill you are at minus 1
              If your skill is higher than your force you get to add 1
              • Jedi mind trick: force replaces coercion
              • Jedi TK: force replaces prowess
              • Jedi agility: force replaces deftness
              Joe-Jedi
              would have a good/fair lightsaber/force or fair/good lightsaber/force
              • would have at least 8 techniques (12 if good force skill)
              • the basic 6 plus one Form I lightsaber (tier one)
              The Basic Six
               
              TK
              leap
              sprint
              sense force
              telepathy
              (missing)
               
              Force ticks (revamp)
              Force ticks will now work health and composure. (in calculating the total number of boxes, and when you fill-up, resulting in consequences)
              After you fill-up and begin accruing consequences you can still use force ticks at the cost of health or(and?) composure.

              | 2284|2284|2007-03-16 09:32:37|David Beebe|rules stuff we talked about|
              Dark Side rework:
               
              Dark Side Aspect- you get a darkside aspect. The darkside aspect generates darkside force points. You can spend dark side force points for +3 or a re-roll +1. 
               
              Missing:
              How do you fall deeper into the dark side?
              How do you remove Dark Side aspects?
               
              BB's Suggestion:
              Use of dark side points puts semi-permanent stress points into your force-use stress meter. If that meter gets filled, another aspect is added. (or the aspect is made more pronounced)
               
              A werewolf the apoc analogy:
              You could have different levels of an aspect.
              Tainted (new moon) 1 dark side points on refresh
              Tempted (crescent) 3 dark side points on refresh
              Teetering (half) 5 dark side points on refresh
              Falling (gibbous) 7 dark side points on refresh
              Lost (full moon) 9 dark side points on refresh
               
              If the Troop decides you have fallen into the next category you have. To climb back out of the category you have to do something heroic and selfless.

              | 2286|2286|2007-03-19 12:28:24|widderslainte|Consequences|
              I found this enlightening. I don't think we're taking advantage of some
              of the options consequences offer:

              http://forum.rpg.net/showthread.php?p=7057870#post7057870

              widderslainte@comcast.net
              | 2287|2286|2007-03-19 17:31:20|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Consequences|
              Here's the relevant post from the thread Shawn sent. I
              like the second idea a lot where you buy off stress
              with Consequences and if you exceed your stress track
              you go right to Taken Out.

              -NB

              Here's what I'd do to make Fate hurt more. Some of
              this is going to show its face in the Dresden Files
              RPG because ... well, we want it to hurt more. (SOTC
              tends to be more a case of heroes who just don't fall
              down a lot -- that's somewhat by design, but we do
              admit it doesn't always work right for everyone.)

              Reduce the number of stress boxes

              The simplest change. Give everyone a base of 2 or 3
              instead of 5, and those fights will start feeling
              painful a lot faster. Making the base 2, you'll
              encounter a setup where 5 stress boxes -- the usual
              default for SOTC -- is what *tough* people get. Should
              feel a bit more right.

              Change how stress boxes behave

              Make 'em act like minion stress boxes (hit points,
              essentially), where if you take a 3-stress hit, you
              mark off 3 boxes. Players may be motivated to walk the
              consequence line minor-major-severe whenever a big hit
              comes in, and let their stress track soak up the
              smaller hits by degrees.

              Change how consequences work.

              Make the stress track work like this: when you exceed
              your stress boxes, you're taken out. Period.

              Consequences let you do this: reduce the amount of
              stress you take from a particular blow.

              Take a minor consequence for a -2 to the stress dealt.
              Take a major consequence for a -4 to the stress dealt.
              Take a severe consequence for a -6 to the stress
              dealt.

              I find this makes fights pretty interesting. Suppose
              you have a 5-box stress track. Someone nails you
              massively, a 8 point hit. Taking a minor consequence
              isn't going to do it -- that's a 6, and still beyond
              your stress track. You have to take a major one, at
              least, to make it work, taking it to a 4, and
              thankfully landing inside your stress track. The nice
              thing about this is it breaks up the predictability of
              the minor->major->severe consequence path.

              Combine 2 or more of the above methods

              You want super lethal? Combine all three. A base of 2,
              acting like hitpoints, with stress reducing
              consequences and a "you run out of stress, you're
              taken out" philosophy will keep things smooth and fast
              but will harken back to the terrifying lethality of
              your Rolemaster days.

              Take any two of the above and you're still gonna see a
              lot of blood hit the pavement.



              ____________________________________________________________________________________
              We won't tell. Get more on shows you hate to love
              (and love to hate): Yahoo! TV's Guilty Pleasures list.
              http://tv.yahoo.com/collections/265

              don't know how often we've been dictating the terms (for either) or
              taking consequences instead of boxes. When it's more than a stress box
              with an aspect, Crippling Blow becomes pretty nasty.

              | 2292|2286|2007-03-20 08:23:22|David Beebe|Re: Consequences|
              Three consequences and a person is 'taken out' is why consequences matter. (and why having the stunt which allows you to give consequences in lieu of stress is pretty damn cool)
               
              If I recall, Vader hit ObiWan for +15 and just dropped him. I just assumed that the excesively high number meant that the minor consequence rolled up to a moderate rolled up to a severe rolled up to "taken out".
               
              Personally if I wanted to play a fragile character I'd vote for GURPS or some such 'realistic' system.   But we're playing heros and jedi to boot. We just need to figure out how to do more damage.  (I'd vote for us getting more stunts)
               
               
              of course it requires three stunts to get there: Crippling Blow requires Dirty Fighter requires Brawler
               
              and Signature strike is even more nasty because it has the potential to do two consequences in a round!
               
              Fist of Death>Lethal Weapon>Martial Arts - again another comibnation of stunts that results in the
               
              our biggest problem:
              we're cursed by our dice
              Nathaniel rolls PIMP on the same dice.

              | 2293|2286|2007-03-20 08:47:28|widderslainte|Re: Consequences|
              On 3/20/07, David Beebe <thedavidbeebe@gmail.com> wrote:

              > If I recall, Vader hit ObiWan for +15 and just dropped him. I just assumed that the > excesively high number meant that the minor consequence rolled up to a moderate rolled > up to a severe rolled up to "taken out".

              My point is that there is no "rolled up". He's only taken out if all
              three consequences have been used. They aren't "negative hit points".

              > of course it requires three stunts to get there: Crippling Blow requires Dirty Fighter > requires Brawler

              Which is why I liked it as part of Form II ;)
              | 2294|2294|2007-03-20 09:19:34|David Beebe|consequences|
              consequences matter because
               
              a) after three consequences your opponent is dropped
              b) they become visible aspects folks can tag (and there are stunts like "dirty fighter" which when you tag an opponent, you get +1 to, making it +3 vs the +2 you would get on your own aspect.
              c) you can tag them in addition to your own aspects for larger numbers (at the cost of fate points)
               
              the bottleneck appears to be limited currency of fatepoints compounded with the fact that the dice are unfriendly to us. :-)
               
              Nathaniel has made the seperate point that
              Consequences on PCs have happened once or twice in 14 sessions.
              which seems to imply that we're not taking enough damage.
               
              I'm in favor of trying the method where
              a) stress boxes fill up (if 3 damage, take three stress boxes)
              -or-
              b) NPCs hitting for more damage
              | 2295|2294|2007-03-20 10:05:42|widderslainte|Re: consequences|

              | 2300|2299|2007-03-20 15:41:58|David Beebe|Re: Stress Card|
              ah-ha! I just figured out where my incorrect mind-set was coming from for the consequences and overflow.
               
              I had incorrectly assumed that if you had seven damage done to you (with five stress boxes)
              you took the seventh spot (in this case the second consiquence- or the moderate consequence)
               
              - which is why Obiwan died so easy. because well he had spilled over damage wise to "taken out" (at Plus 15)
               
              My incorrect base assumption was that if you do 9 plus damage to a regular named dude with no extra endurance, you "one shoted" them.
               
               
               
               
              .


              | 2301|2301|2007-03-20 21:50:10|widderslainte|Galaxy Map|

              linked on the wiki compared. The one I found is not as detailed, but

              Alderaan is missing from this map."

              | 2303|2301|2007-03-21 09:31:26|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Galaxy Map|
              > Then I went back to looking at the fancy one, noting
              > planets I
              > recognized, and suddenly realized, "Where is
              > Alderaan? I think
              > Alderaan is missing from this map."
              >
              > Doh.
              >

              Alderaan is on both maps. Its in section M10 on the
              fancy map.

              The less detailed map you found is pretty cool since
              it mostly sticks to the important planets and doesn't
              overwhelm the eye.

              One map related issue is the location of Taloraan. Its
              a canon planet, but I haven't found it on any of the
              half dozen maps or mapping sites. So that means we get
              to decide where it is!

              Here's what we know about Taloraan's location:
              "Taloraan was the largest planet in the Kelavine
              system of the Expansion Region, with a diameter of
              100,000 kilometers."

              The less detailed map doesn't include the Exapansion
              Region which is between the Inner Rim and Mid Rim so
              use your imagination to add it to Shawn's map.

              Any votes on where we place Taloraan or shall we just
              wait until its specific location becomes important? It
              might be a useful idea catalyst to place it on the map somewhere.

              | 2304|2288|2007-03-21 12:52:28|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: the great jedi escape.|
              > *Suggestions:*
              > Tell Gardula about Jabba's offer.
              > announce we're rebuilding the jedi order and we need
              > her holocron and her
              > two top slaves.
              > offer in trade this "other holocron" we have the one
              > from the jedi
              > intercepter
              > offer to remove the 'thorn in her side' that is
              > jabba (for two slaves)
              >
              > explode into action at the tournement with swinging,
              > leaping from camera
              > droid to camera droid, in the meantime soln and
              > possibly akiban can tie-up
              > jabba's champion this bobba dude.

              Any thoughts on this?

                          | 2320|2320|2007-03-23 16:08:07|widderslainte|Cool Idea from RPG Tips|
                          "this weekend our
                          GM brought something new: little ceramic bathroom tiles.
                          They were just under an inch to a side, so they fit nicely
                          inside the battlemap grid, and he used the same wet erase
                          markers we use for the map to mark damage and status effects
                          right on the tiles, which easily wiped off when the battle
                          was done. Best of all, our GM said 50 of them cost him
                          roughly $2 at the local hardware store."

                          S.
                          | 2321|2321|2007-03-26 11:24:01|David Beebe|we on for thursday?|

                                ---------- Forwarded message ----------
                                From: "David Beebe" <thedavidbeebe@gmail.com>

                                Subject: Re: Starfall
                                 
                                When Han, ObiWan and Luke get brought on board the Death Star.
                                ObiWan is able to get to the tractor beam reactor and turn it off
                                Luke and Han are able to get to the prison cell and break out Leia
                                There is much ado about a ton of firefights going on, but it isn't like the four/five of them are ever against THE WHOLE DEATH STAR.
                                 
                                I think that having extra people for the sense of reality isn't needed. I fear that minions will either gum up the dice rolling and the action. (though our chances of surviving will be a lot higher wiht some expendable fodder!) (i guess Endor with the advance strike team to get into the bunker gomes to mind)

                                > *Scuttle the Ship*
                                > *Mission Checkpoints*
                                >
                                >    - Get From Ship to an "unused Officer Briefing
                                > Room" without causing
                                >    alarms
                                >       - reward - costumes, computer terminal
                                >    - Knock out key camera and internal com system
                                >       - reward - limited access to the ship
                                >    - Travel to Radio Antenna array to Eliminate long
                                > range radio
                                >    transmission capability
                                >       - reward- prevent the world from coming down
                                > on this location
                                >    - Simultaniously take two positions to plant arm
                                > detonation charges
                                >       - reward - controled explosions that render
                                > the ship inert
                                >    - Establish evacuation protocol (ship is in
                                > stable orbit but life
                                >    support will fail in 15 minutes)
                                >       - reward -get into escape pods that get picked
                                > up by  a smaller
                                >       cruiser for hijacking

                                  > that the plan or are we launching the mission with
                                  > just the PCs? I'm cool either way.

                                  | 2346|2343|2007-04-18 14:21:36|David Beebe|Re: Game plan?|
                                  I think that from Nathaniel's arguments for using minions as the games rules allow, and from his in-game characterizations of us 'helping others' it makes the most sense to:
                                   
                                  a) flashback to the rebel meeting 'just before the bar scene' wherein they suggest that we take and scuttle the star destroyer, and we help them make this happen. (we also don't need to R-P this if we don't want to)
                                   
                                  b) get on board the shuttle with our new minions
                                   
                                  c) follow a set of events that leads to the scuttling of the ship with safe egress for both our minions and the people on the ship.
                                   
                                  make sure:
                                  1) it is obvious that jedi were involved
                                  2) the ship doesn't crash land on the planet and destroy tons of innocents
                                   
                                  d) hijack a smaller ship that will come to the rescue of the big ship.

                                  | 2355|2355|2007-04-20 10:24:12|widderslainte|UnderRun - ForgottenPunk|
                                  From some notes long ago:

                                  Dalereckoning 1299

                                  After the royal family was killed, the jewels stolen, and Evermeet
                                  leveled by the Drow, the Sun Elves are out for Blood. The Dwarven
                                  nations have finally replenished their populations and dream of retaking
                                  their subterranean kingdoms. The Zhentarim blew up Waterdeep leaving a
                                  giant crater between Skullport and Undermountain. The Gnomes of Lantan
                                  have become addicted to exotic dreamspices of the East and now sell their
                                  steam-powered mechanical monstrosities to fund their habit. Roam the
                                  Underdark and hire on for assassinations between Drow families. Augment
                                  your psionic powers through illithid-flesh biografts. Grab your
                                  handcrossbow, katana, and mirror-spectacles. Blah Blah Blah.

                                      | 2368|2368|2007-05-17 12:26:35|widderslainte|No offense to poker chips...|
                                      "It doesn't have much in the way of game-appropriate aesthetic appeal,
                                      but paper clips are really handy for counters. Colored ones are easy
                                      to see, and you can clip 'em right onto your character sheet if you
                                      like, or make chains out of them if it's more convenient."

                                      I like the ability to chuck a poker chip across the table, but having
                                      red paper clips to represent dark side points might be pretty handy,
                                      since they stay pretty stable from session to session.

                                      S.

                                          | 2385|2385|2007-06-04 14:23:57|widderslainte|SciFi Reference|
                                          This isn't Star Wars specific, but I thought with rotating GMs, someone would find this useful:

                                          http://rpgbooks.wikia.com/wiki/Trinity_Storytellers_Handbook
                                          | 2386|2386|2007-06-05 09:34:17|Nathaniel Bennett|Fate Point point|
                                          Interesting point from an rpg.net thread about SotC:
                                          http://forum.rpg.net/showthread.php?p=7387800#post7387800.

                                          Now, here's the crucial question -- one that the GM in
                                          this situation should be thinking about as well. Do
                                          you have buyer's remorse about your five shifts?

                                          If you have no remorse -- because those extra shifts
                                          became mondo stress on the bad guy, because they were
                                          spent to reduce the time it took to do the thing you
                                          were doing from hours to mere minutes, because they
                                          were used to get you two extra really juicy facts from
                                          the crime scene you're rooting around -- then, great!
                                          You overshot, but overshooting just made you that much
                                          more of a badass. Things are working as designed.

                                          If on the other hand you do regret overspending,
                                          there's a problem, because it means those five shifts
                                          aren't giving you any kind of value. So here's a rule
                                          of thumb: If you can't turn excess shifts into making
                                          the results of an action more awesome, you shouldn't
                                          be "held to" having spent the fate points to get those
                                          extra shifts.


                                          ___________________________________________________________________________________

                                              | 2500|2499|2008-01-17 11:48:35|Nathaniel Bennett|Re: Street Maps|
                                              Also I was thinking about the need for a strategic map. I think the Company rules from Reign we were looking at last night may be abstract enough that a map of specific territories wouldn't be neccessary. I'm not discouraging one if it would be easy to put together, but to my mind that seems like it would be much easier to outline/stat out the other gangs and leave the geographic details up to dramatic need rather then a map. Thoughts?

                                              | 2503|2503|2008-01-21 16:00:32|widderslainte|Character Creation|
                                              Here's what we came up with the other night:

                                              5 Aspects:
                                              * Occupation
                                              * Relationship
                                              * Flaw
                                              ** Pick two from:  Gear/Props, Phrase, Attribute, Streetlife, Background

                                              Skills
                                              * Standard Pyramid (One Great, Two Good, etc)
                                              * Use skills from Spirit of Century with two additions: Electronics, Computers

                                              3 Stunts - Cyberware will be wrapped into this, or a wholesale addition.  If you think bodymods are important to your character concept, resolve a stunt slot until we can discuss further.
                                              | 2509|2509|2008-01-23 16:09:16|widderslainte|You are already playing.|
                                              http://erdtman.com/holken/lacuna/

                                              Self.  Explanatory.
                                              | 2586|2584|2008-03-28 14:27:35|David Beebe|Re: Fwd: Today's Idea List|
                                              7thish, an system which has a stat of Panache is a winner!

                                              On Fri, Mar 28, 2008 at 2:24 PM, Scott Kunian <skunian@yahoo.com> wrote:

                                              Dark Heresy rules!!
                                               
                                              Another hot up and coming game you might be interested in www.alphaomegathegame.com also check www.mindstormlabs.com for cool downloads/samples.

                                              ----- Original Message ----
                                              From: widderslainte <widderslainte@gmail.com>
                                              To: Uod List <uod@yahoogroups.com>
                                              Sent: Friday, March 28, 2008 2:19:16 PM
                                              Subject: [uod] Fwd: Today's Idea List

                                              Here are the campaign concepts that are bubbling in my skull right
                                              now. In most cases I'm not sold one using any particular system. I
                                              know most of you said you play whatever had momentum, but I thought
                                              I'd throw these out for feedback.

                                              * 7th-ish Pirate/Swashbucklin g (Pseudo Earth w/ Magic)

                                              * Lo5 Rings (Samurai Pseudo Earth w/ Magic)
                                              * Fantasy Tax Collection (System and Setting TDB, though I have ideas)
                                              * Midnight (Again System and Setting Changes TDB)
                                              * Shadowrun - still play runners, but aim for a little different setup
                                              than mercs for corps
                                              * Underrun, but not with D&D (True20, SotC ???)
                                              * Vampire (though it may be too heavy for a weeknight)
                                              * Fading Suns/Dark Heresy



                                              Be a better friend, newshound, and know-it-all with Yahoo! Mobile. Try it now.


                                              | 2589|2589|2008-05-22 10:50:14|widderslainte|Nemesis in a Nutshell in a Nutshell|
                                              Dice rolls at D10 pools based on Stat + Skill (like World of
                                              Darkness). If two dice in your poll match, you have a success.

                                              I roll Coordination + Athletics to climb a wall. My dice pool is 6.
                                              The dice read: 1,2,2,5,8,10. I have a pair of twos, so I succeed.

                                              In combat, the dice rolls say a lot more.

                                              Player A rolls and gets 2,5,6,7,10,10. The only "set" is two 10s
                                              (2x10). That's two points of damage to hit location 10 (the head),
                                              modified by weapons and armour.

                                              Player B rolls and gets 1,4,7,7,7,9. The set is three 7s. (3x7).
                                              That's three points of damage to hit location 7 (the body), again
                                              modified by weapons and armour.

                                              The player with the "wider" (number of dice that match) set hits
                                              first, so player B strikes first.

                                              That's all with one roll, hence One Roll Engine (ORE). There's a
                                              bunch more that can be added such as combat manuevers (dodge, parry,
                                              disarm, etc), martial disciples (kind of like feat chains for
                                              fighters) and obviously weapons and armor. FWIW, if that hit to the
                                              head by Player A was with a good weapon and Player B didn't have a
                                              helmet, might be enough to kill.

                                              All the rules are here:
                                              http://www.nemesis-system.com/

                                              S.
                                              | 2592|2592|2008-07-16 16:30:15|widderslainte|Using Aspects with ORE|
                                              From the master himself. Made for stunts, but should be the correct
                                              probabilities. Only problem might be stacking fate points to get
                                              pools over 10D.

                                              >The simplest, hand-wavin'est route is just to glue on some kind of stunting rules. Described something cool? Add a die or offset a penalty. >Very cool? +2d or offset a -2d penalty. Very cool AND accidentally helps the GM's plans? +MD or something.
                                              >
                                              >-G.
                                              | 2594|2594|2008-11-17 15:14:09|widderslainte|A hundred thousand years|
                                              A hundred thousand years before Columbus or Cook, the Lemurian Empire
                                              stretched from their sunken homeland between Asia and Australia north
                                              to the Himalayas, south to Tasmania and New Zealand, and east to the
                                              Rocky Mountains. They ruled the world when another race - the
                                              half-vegetable things of Algol's second planet - descended to earth,
                                              and fought a war with bows and spears against star-crossing technology
                                              - and had partial success. The Algolians' technology, a weird hybrid
                                              of DNA and silicon, decayed on Earth, and the ancient race had
                                              forgotten the potential of even primitive technology when backed by
                                              the spirit and courage of a still-young species. The decaying race was
                                              forced into the deserts of Australia, scene of the war's most
                                              devastating conflicts.

                                              There, the mightiest Algolian weapons had been used - corruptors of
                                              the Earth. Many of their bio-weapons had the side-effect of mutating
                                              the local fauna to be more deadly; this can be seen in the region even
                                              to this day. The changing Algolian biotechnology, its mutation speeded
                                              by the radiation from several nuclear strikes, produced vast monsters
                                              - towers of bone, flesh, wood, leaf, and venom. These creatures
                                              devoured the Algolians, their unwitting creators, eliminating them
                                              wholly from the earth.

                                              The monsters then raged across the lands of Earth, forming a far direr
                                              threat to the Lemurians than the Algolian War itself. In the terrible
                                              conflict, the monsters were destroyed, but the Lemurian Empire was so
                                              damaged that it decayed to stone-age levels and vanished in a few
                                              centuries.

                                              Though the first generation was destroyed, monsters still breed from
                                              all the sites of Algolian warfare - Australia primarily, but also
                                              areas scattered throughout Eurasia and the Pacific Rim. It is these
                                              monsters that were slain by all the heroes of legend. If the world is
                                              free of monsters for a long time - five centuries or a millennium -
                                              they will be all the more terrible they will be when they at last
                                              re-appear. And the last monsters were slain fifteen centuries ago.
                                              | 2595|2595|2008-11-20 21:09:29|widderslainte|Inspiring thoughts to keep Yahoo from killing the list|
                                              "The Guardians of Order version of EPT that came out a few years back
                                              was good, but it was really trying to be respectable and slick, and
                                              was more about an alien culture than anything your characters might
                                              actually do in that culture. It was the kind of RPG you might show
                                              your anthropology-major buddy to prove to him that roleplaying wasn't
                                              just for kids. It was yuppie T'ekumel. This old version is raw, uncut
                                              T'ekumel: You are savage barbarian adventurers living among the dregs
                                              of an ancient, racist empire on a world with no white people, no
                                              horses, and no stars in the sky.You crawl down into the Underworld
                                              with your wicked zig-zag swords and fight acid-trip nightmares for
                                              glory, citizenship, and the awesome power of ancient technology. Then
                                              you crawl back up to blow all your gold on sex slaves and drugs at the
                                              temples of insane gods in teeming, decadent cities. Fuck that wannabe
                                              Dark Sun... this is the real deal."

                                              Uod needs more drugs and sex slaves.
                                              | 2596|2596|2008-12-24 10:13:23|shawnbarrick|I got a PDF today...|
                                              "I got a PDF today of the original 1975 TSR version of EMPIRE OF THE
                                              PETAL THRONE, Professor M.A.R. Barker's cult RPG set in his world of
                                              T'ekumel, a fantasy setting that he allegedly first created in the
                                              40's and turned into a lifelong obssessive project. I have been
                                              reading though it this evening.

                                              Jesus...this is so eccentric, personal, trippy, bizarre, jagged,
                                              beautiful, crude, and imaginative. It's Edgar Rice Burroughs meets
                                              1960's psychedellic culture meets Imperial China meets the Aztecs in a
                                              dark alley behind a brothel in Tangiers, where they bump into a
                                              drunken Tolkien and violently sodomize him on a pile of garbage while
                                              he begs them not to stop. I can fucking smell the hash smoke coming
                                              through the screen of my monitor.

                                              The Guardians of Order version of EPT that came out a few years back
                                              was good, but it was really trying to be respectable and slick, and
                                              was more about an alien culture than anything your characters might
                                              actually do in that culture. It was the kind of RPG you might show
                                              your anthropology-major buddy to prove to him that roleplaying wasn't
                                              just for kids. It was yuppie T'ekumel. This old version is raw, uncut
                                              T'ekumel: You are savage barbarian adventurers living among the dregs
                                              of an ancient, racist empire on a world with no white people, no
                                              horses, and no stars in the sky.You crawl down into the Underworld
                                              with your wicked zig-zag swords and fight acid-trip nightmares for
                                              glory, citizenship, and the awesome power of ancient technology. Then
                                              you crawl back up to blow all your gold on sex slaves and drugs at the
                                              temples of insane gods in teeming, decadent cities. Fuck that wannabe
                                              Dark Sun... this is the real deal. "
                                              | 2597|2597|2009-01-20 16:36:28|widderslainte|A story|
                                              The Magician climbed the stairs. Midnight found him in his study,
                                              pouring through leather-bound tomes and untidy portfolios... At one
                                              time a thousand or more runes, spells, incantations, curses, and
                                              sorceries had been known. The reach of Grand Motholam--Ascolais, the
                                              Ide of Kauchique, Almery to the South, the Land of the Falling Wall to
                                              the East--swarmed with sorcerers of every description, of whom the
                                              chief was the Arch-Necromancer Phandaal. A hundred spells Phandaal
                                              personally had formulated--though rumor said that demons whispered at
                                              gus ear when he wrought magic. Pontecilla the Pious, then ruler of
                                              Grand Motholam, put Phandall to torment, and after a terrible night,
                                              he killed Phandaal and outlawed sorcery throughout the land. The
                                              wizards of Grand Motholam fled like beetles under a strong light; the
                                              lore was dispersed and forgotten, until now, at this dim time, with
                                              the sun dark, wilderness obscuring Ascolais, and the white city Kaiin
                                              half in ruins, only a few more than a hundred spells remained to the
                                              knowledge of man. Of these, Mazirian had access to seventy-three, and
                                              gradually, by stratagem and negotiation, was securing the others.

                                              Maziriam made a selection from his books and with great effort
                                              forced five spells upon his brain: Phandaal's Gyrator, Felojun's
                                              Second Hypnotic Spell, The Excellent Prismatic Spray, The Charm of
                                              Untiring Nourishment, and the Spell of the Omnipotent Sphere. This
                                              accomplished, Maziriam drank wine and retired to his couch.
                                              | 2598|2598|2009-04-13 15:11:10|widderslainte|Dying Earth Rules.|
                                              "The pages of my copy of Thrupp’s famous tome of demonic
                                              lore were of more use for cleaning our posteriors during the
                                              terrible incarceration we suffered in the dungeons of Dactza’s
                                              iron metropolis. My companion, Hashmair (before we were
                                              unfortunately forced to consume him in order to assuage our
                                              pending starvation) suggested that we had been sold a forgery.
                                              This possibility has to be given some credence. When I regain
                                              my health, Fianosther will experience gross unpleasantness "

                                              – Malastor of Kaiin
                                              | 2599|2599|2009-04-16 12:11:00|widderslainte|The Magosh of Sofegai|
                                              "We had been waiting. The same day we toppled the Mindat control of
                                              our cities, he arrived"

                                              The day the Heteri people claimed their independence, The Magosh
                                              entered the ruling keep of Sofegai. He has held that seat as vuhwul
                                              of Sofegai for 200 years.

                                              There were concerns at first. Despite being a man of the north, he
                                              studied under the Mindat scholars, enemies of the Heteri. Servants
                                              claimed he did not sleep and was a hermaphrodite. Stubs of horns were
                                              apparent beneath his hair, and his massive jaws and teeth matched the
                                              frame that towered over the largest of Heteri men.

                                              Despite the questions and rumours, no one challenged him. During his
                                              reign he has rebuilt the city walls to greater heights, erected new
                                              temples to the gods and while ruling the region with an iron fist is
                                              beloved by his citizens. The Magosh claims to have the blood of Utan
                                              the Destroyer flowing in his veins, and every night lights braziers in
                                              the keep to honour the Coal God. The people are content.

                                              -----------------------
                                              http://sites.google.com/site/worldofuod/
                                              | 2600|2600|2009-04-16 16:55:20|widderslainte|Inspiration: FATE of Reign|
                                              Stolen from rpg.net forums:

                                              Aspects: Obsessions, Taboos (perhaps Passion, Fear and Rage as well).

                                              Each type of Insanity is a gauge like the social conflict - instead of one composure track, each Insanity track is one track, and in social conflict your goal is to focus on the weakest track; each time you take a permanent tick in the gauge, you get an aspect. If your opponent find out about that, good luck. Empathy allows you to get a read through interaction, Deceit blocks Empathy, Resolve allows you to prevent damage (set a difficulty of the shock/social stress and roll your Resolve vs. that)

                                              This Risus setting has come good material as well:
                                              http://www.rpglibrary.org/settings/roughmagic/
                                              | 2601|2601|2009-04-20 11:39:14|widderslainte|The Heteri City of Narrosh|
                                              Narrosh lies in the mountainous northwest corner of Ghikarn.  It is ruled over by the Vuhwul Ergror Nikai, whose Verdant Valley clan has ruled the city since before the Mindat occuptation.  The Punluggai tribes of the region how sway beyond the mountains, and have their Maetah slaves bring tribute of grains and crops to the city.  Night and day, weary pale-skinned slaves carry massive baskets of goods through the eastern mountain passes for the city coffers. 

                                              Narrosh is known for two things:  Slaves and Coal.  The same Maetah slaves carrying goods into city are funnelled into the market, which maintains the largest slave trading ring on the continent.  From Narrosh most are sent south to Sofegai, or west to Bolog, a vassal city-state that supplies foodstuffs and other staple goods rare in the mountains. 

                                              The mountains surrouding Narrosh provide a steady supply of coal and ore, and all the mercantile clans of the city pay the Coal God homage for these gifts.  The city center is dominated by a massive temple complex for the worship and study of Hilinavyu, the Coal God, Lord of Earth, Fire, Home an Hearth, and the Secrets of the Mountain.  Great braziers line the city walls and tops of temples, burning day and night, and no one can enter either of the city gates without walking between massive statues of Hilinavyu, carved out the mountain itself.  The Vuhwul's clan are ardent scholars of the Secrets of the Mountain, and it is said the shining black coal eyes in every city statue are the eyes of Nikai watching you.


                                              | 2602|2602|2009-04-22 16:57:56|widderslainte|Teaeshe Naam, Slave Lord of Narrosh|
                                              Taeshe Naam is a massive, wrinkly, shell of a man.  His mere glance frightens children and the scuttling approach of the nogs carrying his palanquin can settle a dispute.  Taeshe has a booming laugh, a boisterious manner, and makes a delerious profit running the slave market of Narrosh. 

                                              Taeshe Naam was an aspiring student in the Duslangarot sorceror's lodge until an alchemical accident left him scarred, crippled, and unabled to walk.  He spent the following years running the books on his family's grain trade in the city market.  When his father fell victim to a gang dispute, Naam called in favours from his old mentor and reapplied himself to the study of alchemy.  After the leaders of all the major slave trading gangs fell ill and found their wares mysteriously poisoned, Naam stepped in to oversee there operations.

                                              Uneasy truce with Vuhwul Nakai.  Naam knows Nakai could shut down his operations with little more than a thought, but it would take years to hope to achieve the cooperation of the slavers beyond city-state's reach and the numerous gangs with a hand in city's market and export operations.
                                              | 2603|2603|2009-04-23 16:34:35|widderslainte|The Snail People|
                                              Beneath the mountains of Bolog and Cuvauw dwell the Snail People in their domed caverns. They lounge in huts and tubes of moss and dried mucus, studying tomes of ancient lore and practicing with epees. All the while the peasant class of slug tend to the mushroom farms and algae pools.  Their most special fungi will cause hallucinations and give the imbiber a view into the dream realms.

                                              Sorcerers from the Dusanglarot Lodge claim the Snail People taught them the secrets of alchemy and that the goblins of the south are a result of their early experiments.


                                              | 2604|2604|2009-04-24 16:17:04|widderslainte|The Righteous & Most Glorious Children of the World|
                                              Believed to be an offshoot of modern Mindat philosophies, The Righteous & Most Glorious Children of the World are a small cult that has recently reemerged in towns along the Minkush River.  They are not know to be violent, but many rumours have them robbing or burning temples in that area.  The cult has been dormant for three decades, after most of the cells had been thought purged by mercenaries and bounty hunters in the employ of the Church of Thedine.

                                              The Righteous & Most Glorious Children of the World believe that the world is corrupt and broken and needs to be born anew.  Destroying the gods is not enough. Annihaliation of the material plane must occur.  The Children of the World seek out legends and knowledge of the apocalypse and attempt to further its enacting.

                                              Believed to be an offshoot of modern Mindat philosophies, The Righteous & Most Glorious Children of the World are a small cult that has recently reemerged in towns along the Minkush River.  They are not know to be violent, but many rumours have them robbing or burning temples in that area.  The cult has been dormant for three decades, after most of the cells had been thought purged by mercenaries and bounty hunters in the employ of the Church of Thedine.

                                              The Righteous & Most Glorious Children of the World believe that the world is corrupt and broken and needs to be born anew.  Destroying the gods is not enough. Annihaliation of the material plane must occur.  The Children of the World seek out legends and knowledge of the apocalypse and attempt to further its enacting.
